PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been prohibited by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Video Material has concluded that ``Adverse effects upon people, and especially upon children, of exposure to material containing various degrees of violence, pornography or obscenity have been demonstrated''.
The majority of the Select Committee strongly opposed the proposition for a new NVE (non-violent erotica) category, which would have entrenched X-rated video pornography.
All six State Governments have, through their Attorneys-General, expressed unanimous opposition to the circulation of X-rated videos.
We consider the continuing distribution of X-rated videos from the A.C.T. to be reprehensible and to be contrary to the wellbeing of the Australian community in general.
We strongly request urgent Government action to prohibit the distribution of X-rated and excessively violent video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland: Disaster Relief Funds
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:

We are concerned that the National Party in Queensland is diverting money given by the Federal Government to the Queensland Government to alleviate natural disasters; that it might not be finding its way to its intended targets; and that it is being diverted to the coffers of the National Party itself or otherwise to expansion projects promoted by members or supporters of the National Party.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament; the humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
That Kingsford-Smith Airport is becoming increasingly congested and existing facilities are inadequate to handle the number of aircraft or their passengers.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace Tax Fund
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully brings to your attention:
that there are individuals who have a conscientious objection to war because of their religious or general moral principles
and that the Parliament of this country has already recognised the right of such individuals not to have to participate in military service in time of war
and that all Australian taxpayers are required to contribute to military expenditure, regardless of their beliefs, through that part of their tax that is used for the Defence budget

and that while we acknowledge the right of the Government to levy taxes and to decide on the expenditure of monies so collected we cannot accept that those with a conscientious objection to war should be forced to contribute to military expenditure

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement to the Senate regarding a question asked of me by Senator Reid yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Reid asked me about an alteration to the transcript of an answer I gave on 17 October 1988 as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. The facts concerning Senator Reid's question are as follows. She asked me a question on `health nutrition' on 12 October 1988 which at the time I put on notice. I obtained an answer by the end of Question Time on that day and then read it into the Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: On 17 October I added to my answer of 12 October. The Daily Hansard of 17 October contains in my answer the words `. . . however, the scientific positions will be retained'. These words were deleted by Hansard, at the request of one of my staff, in the final Hansard record, the Weekly Hansard. The request for the deletion was made because after 17 October the Department of Community Services and Health advised my office that Hansard needed a correction. I did not understand this to be a request for an important or substantial change, and certainly not one that would alter the sense of the answer. As I have said, Hansard was approached and the alteration was made.

The silly thing is that the words could have stood and, indeed, could now be reinserted. There was certainly never any intention on my part to misinform, confuse or conceal anything from Senator Reid or the Senate. Now that Senator Reid has drawn my attention to the matter I have reread the question and the answers and can see that, from her point of view, she has some cause to complain that the meaning may have been altered. Alternatively, I can see how my staff and Hansard could be of a contrary view. However, it would be wrong for me to quibble about this and the words should go back in. That would be consistent with my wish to answer completely and fully. I formally request that the words be put back in. I especially do not wish Hansard or my staff to be blamed for what has happened. I believe the buck must stop with me. I accept the responsibility for the circumstance and I apologise to the Senate for it.

I now turn to the real issue raised by Senator Reid in her question relating to the nutrition section of the Department of Community Services and Health. In view of yesterday's developments I again asked the Department whether there was any further explanatory information that could be provided. It advised:

There has been no reduction in the number of science officers in the nutrition area since the recent organisational changes nor has the Department any plans to reduce the number of science officers in that area in the next financial year.
Finally, so I can assure Senator Reid on this point, if for any reason the situation should change I undertake to let her know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) censures the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) for the improper alteration to the Hansard transcript of 17 October 1988 to alter the sense of his answer to a question relating to nutrition services provided by the Department of Community Services and Health; and

(b) calls on the President to enforce strictly the rule that Senators' corrections to Hansard must not have the effect of deleting from the record words actually spoken in debate so as to alter the sense of words spoken.

One of the essential tools of the parliamentary process and a tool which has been an essential part of the process for generations now is the issuing of a Hansard record of what is said in this Parliament. What is said in this Parliament is regarded as important. Misleading the Parliament is regarded as one of the few cardinal sins of politics which usually result in the removal of a Minister from his position. On a daily basis we all rely on the Hansard to confirm the comments which have been made, the words which have been spoken, whether by Ministers or senators in this place or, indeed, by Ministers and members of the other chamber. The keeping and accuracy of that record is a matter of fundamental importance to the good operation of the whole parliamentary system.

It is not a new matter to have members of parliament seeking to change the record. Mr President, you would know from your own experience in the chair and from your reading of the history of this place that it goes back to the very beginning of Federation that issues have been raised about the propensity of members to change the parliamentary record. The rules have been clear and well established from virtually the beginning of this century. If we go back to 1906, we find that the Speaker of the House of Representatives laid down a rule in these terms:

No alterations of Hansard are permissible, but corrections are allowed . . . Any member is at liberty to make any corrections which will bring the report into closer agreement with what he actually said.

But alterations of Hansard-that is to say, changes in the sense of what has been said, so that the Hansard report makes an honourable member say something which he did not say, or something of a different tenor-such changes as that, which I deem alterations, and not corrections, are not permissible, and ought not to be attempted by any honourable member.

In the debate on this issue, and the rulings which have been given and the words that have been written since that time, one finds that that fundamental statement remains accurate, and one finds that these words have been blessed by continued usage since they were laid down in about 1918:
Honourable members are respectfully requested to note that emendations which alter the sense of words used in debate or introduce new matter are not admissible.

I doubt whether in this debate there will be any particular difference of view about what the rules are with respect to the operation of Hansard. Again, therefore, I do not wish to labour the point. As Mr Hughes, as a private member of parliament-and I do not think these words will go amiss-said:

Alterations in form but not in substance are properly allowed, because, when an honourable member is addressing the chamber, he is so torn by conflicting emotions and troubled with interjections that his delicate equilibrium is disturbed and he recovers himself only with difficulty.

I am sure that in many cases that is the reason for our ungrammatical expressions, which are so kindly corrected by Hansard-and about which, of course, nobody raises any objection. But in this case we are dealing with a change which, on the Minister's own admission, is a change which is outside the guidelines on what is permitted. In the documents that were attached to the Minister's pinks these words are stated:
Necessary corrections may be made, but alterations of sense or the introduction of new matter are not admissible.
What Senator Cook has clearly admitted, and what the record clearly shows, is that there has been an amendment to the sense of the answer which he gave.

The practical importance of that is demonstrated by the fact that in this case, as I am advised by Senator Reid, this was an answer which was of considerable interest to her constituency, and she in fact circulated the Minister's original answer as reported in the Daily Hansard to those people who had been making representations to her. It was a matter that was regarded as of some moment, and she might have something to say later in the debate about the particular staffing position to which the Minister has referred in his answer today.

This Minister has been courageous enough not to seek to shift the blame to his staff or to departmental officials, and I welcome that because he is the person responsible. What happened in this case is that, not in the emotion of debate but on a considered basis, the Minister put down a statement which was provided for him by the Department of Community Services and Health and then, on the initiative of the Department of Community Services and Health, he brought about the removal of a particular sentence which was of major importance to the answer which was given-namely, that `the scientific positions', which had been queried by Senator Reid, `will be retained'. In those circumstances, we face the situation where there has clearly been a falsification of the record. That is totally unsatisfactory. It is totally destructive of the good operation of this chamber and, indeed, of this Parliament. We believe, therefore, that it is a proper basis for the censure of this Minister.

However, the motion raises a second point which goes to you, Mr President, as the responsible Presiding Officer. Again, it has been long accepted that it is your office that has the final responsibility for the material that appears in the Hansard report. At page 141 of the fifth edition of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice there is reference to the statement of Sir Magnus Cormack, the then President of the Senate, on 26 September 1972 explaining that it was the well-established practice that the President has the final responsibility for the material that appears in the Hansard report of the Senate proceedings. Odgers stated:

For many years the President has exercised this authority to direct the Principal Parliamentary Reporter to expunge from the record objectionable matter, irregular questions and offensive remarks withdrawn at the direction of the Chair.

Mr President, in this motion we call upon you to enforce strictly the rule that senators' corrections to Hansard must not have the effect of deleting from the record words actually spoken in debate so as to alter the sense of words spoken. I think that the Minister's position would have been clear had that been understood as a clear duty of Hansard under your direction. On the basis of what has been put forward by the Minister, he would have been given cause for pause to consider the matter in more detail than he apparently did in making the changes which were made. I believe that it is in the interests of Ministers, as well as all senators, to have that rule strictly enforced. If we are to have a situation where, in excessive enthusiasm, senators or their staff seek to change the meaning of the record which has been taken by Hansard, there should be an automatic check on that or at least a query which will ensure that people are put on guard if this matter arises again. Mr President, I ask you to support the motion in terms of its call to you to ensure that the proper rules are followed.

Senator Cook is entitled to credit for coming into this place and accepting responsibility for the matter which occurred. However, I do not believe that that is a reason for the Senate simply regarding this as a matter which should be let pass. The proper operation of this place is not automatic. As this incident shows, departmental officials and members of ministerial staff are prepared to see a clear falsification of the record take place, and the reason is not explained. The extraordinary thing about the Minister's statement is that he has claimed that the sentence could have stood; that in fact there has been no reduction in the number of scientific places within the Department. That renders even more extraordinary and inexplicable the preparedness of departmental and ministerial office officials to change the clear meaning of the record in this place. If they are prepared to do that in the sorts of circumstances which the Minister has outlined, one could be far less sanguine about the attitude that might be adopted when there is some heavy political import.

One recalls that the last time we debated such a matter it involved Minister Evans, who was then the Attorney-General, who had added a word which he had not said in an answer to a question which he gave in this place. On that occasion there was very detailed debate as to whether or not that had changed the meaning of the statement which had been made. There can be no such debate on this occasion. It is quite clear that there has been a falsification of the record in a quite meaningful sense. In those circumstances, the Opposition believes it is appropriate that the Minister should be censured and that you, Mr President, should be called upon to enforce the proper rules in a strict manner through Hansard, which is ultimately under your control.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the question that Senator Reid asked me on 12 October, we see that she did not explicitly ask me a question on that point. That may well be regarded as a pedantic interpretation of what the question was, because it is obvious from a discussion I had with Senator Reid after the event what the intention of the question was. It was because of that obviousness, and because I had no need to conceal or delay, that a second answer was supplied several days later. That is why there are two answers to this question.

In the second answer there was more elaboration on what Senator Reid was actually asking. What Senator Reid was actually asking was whether the quality of the nutritional services section of the Department of Community Services and Health was to be reduced in any way. She asked that, as is her right, and as is commonly the right of honourable senators, in a political context in the form of an allegation against the Government. If she had asked me explicitly, `Has staffing been reduced?', that would have been an explicit question, but she did not ask me that question. So when my staff interpreted the question they believed, and I believe Hansard believed, that there was no alteration to the semantic meaning of those words and therefore there was no fabrication of the record.

I think it would be entirely unforgivable for any allegation to be made that there was a deliberate attempt to fabricate to be believed in this chamber. I believe that I am entitled to be believed in the explanation that I have given. There was not any attempt to do that. In retrospect, the responsibility or the fault in this matter was that I did not check what it was that was being changed in Hansard after I knew that the Department had some quibble with the answer that was given. As I said, I recall speaking to Senator Reid after the first answer had been given, her indicating to me the question of staffing, and my indication that I would get a more full answer. I knew what she really wanted to know, as opposed to what the pedantic words on the page were.

When the indication was that there may need to be a correction, I did not examine what the correction would be. To that extent, I have been, I believe, in error in not following through all those details. Rather than leave it to my staff, I should have done it myself. Therefore, that explains why my staff and Hansard acted in a way that was consistent with their understanding of the circumstances and why, had I paid closer attention to the issue, the matter would never have arisen. Having made that explanation, I do not believe that there has been a deliberate falsification or a falsification in fact. There has been a quite important misunderstanding, and I have acted at each point to try to assist Senator Reid in getting an answer. I do not resile from that. I hope I will continue to do that in the future.

The other factor that needs to be mentioned goes to the background of this issue. There is something called the establishment figure that departments maintain and there is something called the approved staffing figure that departments maintain. In drawing up tight answers and tight questions on these matters, sometimes there is a propensity to use the establishment figure and the actual staffing figure interchangeably. That is not the case. I think there was in this case some genuine misunderstanding about the context of the positions referred to in Senator Reid's question. Hopefully, the fuller explanation I have given resolves that question. I have promised to continue to do that.

In short, I do not think there is any need for me to make a long speech, other than to say that I do not think it is reasonable or fair, in these circumstances, to hold any allegation against Hansard. It acted properly in all the circumstances of what was before it. I certainly do not think it is proper for me to in any way blame my staff. It is my responsibility. What my staff do is an extension of what I do and that is my responsibility. I accept that. My error was in not matching my personal understanding of the intention of Senator Reid's question with what appeared on the actual page and not following through on that detail. That was a mistake. I regret it. It was a glitch; it was no more than that. I do not believe it was a serious miscarriage of anything. Ministers are human and do make mistakes. But the real question about making mistakes is not that mistakes are made by human beings, but what human beings do when a mistake is made. In these circumstances I believe I have acted properly. I think if one takes a reasonable and wider understanding of the whole circumstances, rather than a narrow and political point-scoring stance, what has occurred is understandable.

On that basis, I do not think the material is a matter for censure. It would be improper for the Senate to move to that level, which is the repudiation of actions taken by Ministers. That is quite serious. I do not think the matter is of that quality. The Senate should not proceed to censure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must join Senator Chaney in commending Senator Cook for accepting the responsibility for the deletion and for apologising to the Senate for that. I know it must be tempting, when one is exceedingly busy, to blame one's staff to whom one does pass on a lot of responsibility. It gives Senator Cook at least some brownie points that he was prepared to accept the full responsibility for this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: However, having said that, I am afraid I cannot agree with his somewhat disingenuous assertion in his explanation that the alterations did not affect the sense of his response. They quite clearly did. They were not extraneous words. They were not the result of tidying up the grammar. They were not an attempt to make sense out of what was, or could perhaps have been, a garbled response. Senator Cook is not in the habit of making garbled responses. I do not think Hansard would have had to spend a great deal of time tidying up his grammar or organising the words he puts together. This matter does not fall into that category.

The change which was made quite clearly alters the sense of the answer to the question asked by Senator Reid. But much more importantly than that, the removal of these particular words removed an undertaking made by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) with regard to the staffing in the nutrition services program. The words deleted were:
. . . however, the scientific positions will be retained.

That is a statement, a commitment, made by the Minister from his position in the Government and in the Parliament. It is not good enough for the Minister to say that the deletion did not alter the sense of the answer-because it clearly did-and that, in any event, if it did alter the sense, it did not really matter. Everything is okay because the guarantee could have been left in. That is a classic parliamentary example of the lawyer's old broken window argument. I admire the honourable senator for thinking of this way out of his dilemma, but it simply is not good enough, because just as easily the reverse could have been true. As Senator Chaney pointed out, it is here that the real problem lies.

Hansard is a record of what is said in this place. Sometimes it is merciful that Hansard gets around to altering some of the things said, or at least the way in which they are said, because I suspect that if what was said were left in its original form, the general public would have even less confidence in the capacity of its elected representatives to cope, or even to think, than it currently has.

TALK.START.PARA: —They make us look a lot better than we are.

—That is absolutely true. Hansard is to be commended for the work that it does in making us sound reasonably intelligent, coherent human beings. But that is entirely separate from the matter that is before us today. Hansard is a record. Under the Acts Interpretation Act it can be used to interpret legislation, to give the courts an idea of what Ministers and the Government intended legislation to mean. It is important, therefore, that Ministers in particular do not abuse this situation by saying one thing in the chamber-whether it is a considered comment or whether it is an off the cuff comment, or whether it is a comment made in the heat of the moment in response to an interjection does not matter-and then feeling free on reflection, mature or otherwise, to change, add to or delete words from their statement.
—That is a good line; I like that-`mature or otherwise'.

—Senator Button may take that on board and use it on another occasion. Around this place it may not be too true too often. It is not a pleasant thing, obviously, to censure a Minister for anything, but it is essential that the Senate and members of the public can rely absolutely on Hansard to report accurately the intentions and the sense of the debate in the Parliament. I do not want to quibble about semantics.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook may not have, in his view, falsified the records. He may have felt, even after deleting the words with regard to the scientific positions, that he still answered Senator Reid's question. But that too is not the point. Whether it was gratuitous or otherwise, the words were said. The undertaking was given, and to remove it causes a considerable problem. Whether he likes it or not, he has certainly changed the sense and, in a very real way, the value of the answer that he gave to Senator Reid. This is simply not acceptable. So for that reason-and with considerable regret, I might say, since I have a personal respect and liking for Senator Cook-we will be supporting Senator Chaney's motion. I hope that the Minister, or anyone else in this place for that matter, will not in future feel free to make changes of this nature.

I can imagine the pressure that can be applied to Hansard by the arguments that can be given by a staff member, a member of parliament or a Minister who feels strongly about wanting things changed, but it is important that we stand by what is said in here and that people do not feel free to make changes to words they regret having said, to words that they find afterwards are in fact not true or to words that are causing a bit of a problem for the Government at the time.

I hope the President, therefore, will strictly enforce the usual conventions regarding changes, in particular additions or deletions, to the record of words spoken in debate where the sense could or would be changed as a result. Nobody in this place actually wants you, Mr President, to make sure that the Hansard daily, weekly or bound versions show exactly what is said in this place because that would only damage the credibility of the Parliament, but we cannot have the credibility of Government Ministers challenged or brought into disrepute in any way. We will be supporting Senator Chaney's motion. I hope that Ministers do not feel free in the future to take out words which they or the Government, on reflection, no longer feel comfortable with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join the debate only briefly. I am bemused by the information that has been given. I do not think the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) has explained what the true position is with this nutrition section. He now says that the words can be replaced and that they need not have been taken out. That really does make me wonder why the words were taken out in the first place, how they ever got into the statement that he read to the Senate, and why someone in the Department of Community Services and Health then felt the matter was sufficiently significant to ask a member of his staff to get them removed. That has not been explained. It is even more significant, given that there are job losses in that area and that the number of people employed is not the same as it was prior to the move.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook in a sense has attempted to suggest that it is all my fault that this happened because my question was not sufficiently explicit in the first place. He suggested that my question was a little political. If that is true, it would not be the first time that a question had been asked in Question Time that had a political overtone to it. In fact, some of the questions from the Government side to its own Ministers are of that nature. Having reread my question of 12 October 1988, I feel quite certain that what I was getting at was absolutely clear. It was clear what I was trying to find out and what I thought about what the Government was doing. I do not resile from making plain what I thought about that. The question contained statements and questions. It is interesting to reflect on the answer the Minister gave initially. His first reaction to my question was to say:
After a long preface-
he cannot suggest I did not tell him what I was on about-
the honourable senator asked three questions, all of which could be classified as `When are you going to stop beating your wife?' . . .

That is the reaction I got to my question on the first bite at it. He then backed away from that fiery encounter and said he would seek a full reply from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), and he did come back at the end of Question Time. He did not at that stage seem to be confused by what I was asking, and he indicated that there would be some staff savings as a result of what was going on. Of course these staff savings, as Senator Cook called them, were confirmed when he came back again on 17 October with a prepared written statement, which he read into the Hansard and which included the words `however, the scientific positions will be retained'.

Mr President, you will not be surprised to know that I posted that reply to all of those people who had contacted me about the downgrading of the nutrition section, as the Government was seeking to use the funds to support the health advancement program. That was the point I was making. I question the integrity of the Minister's staff in indulging in this exercise. I shall not say much about Hansard because it is not in a position to answer in this place. I really do doubt that anybody could think that removing the words `however, the scientific positions will be retained' is not significantly changing the sense of what was being talked about.

The real issue, of course, is that the section has been downgraded. It is two positions down at present. The papers given to the union discussing this show quite clearly that the Government intended to reduce positions in this area-the area of scientific research within the Department dealing with the very important matter of food composition data, the information that tells people, other researchers, doctors, what is in the food we eat. Anyone who does not think that is very important is missing out on a very significant area of knowledge in medical research. The research involves the nutritional intake of Australians and fatty acids in the Australian diet-all absolutely vital. This is the area being downgraded as the Government seeks to move into the area of health advancement, with what I would call a glossy program of endorsement of what it says it wants to do. It is really a promotion of the Government itself rather than a concentration on the real issues.

I spoke about the matter again in the Senate on 28 November, in debate on the Appropriation Bills. I did not specifically refer to the Minister's answer, although I did refer to it when I dealt with the cutback in staff. That is recorded in the Hansard of that date. I did not know at that stage that the Minister had already corrected his answer. What I said then was based on his claim that the Government was not reducing numbers in this section when in fact it has.

There are three issues in this matter. One is the question of the Minister's responsibility which, as has been recognised and acknowledged, he has admitted. However, I am surprised that staff in a Minister's office would do what has been done in this case. I am surprised that Hansard acceded to the request. I say that the Government has downgraded the significance of the area that I was referring to, and I hope that the Minister will let us have further information about it. It is certainly not the last time that I shall mention the matter of research and nutrition in the Senate, but the question before us today is how we manage our affairs and present ourselves to the community. It is quite clear from Odgers' Australian Senate Practice that this alteration ought not to have been made. It says:
Senators may make necessary corrections to the typescript, but emendations altering the sense or introducing new matter are not admissible.
I suggest most strongly that the deletion of the words in question clearly altered the sense of the answer that the Minister gave. I support the motion moved by Senator Chaney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish to speak briefly in response to the debate on my motion. Before I do so, I seek leave to have the motion put in two parts. I do this following a discussion with the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray), whom, in fairness to you, Mr President, I invited to support the second part of the motion. I think that would be an appropriate course.
—I am not sure that leave is required. I think the Chair has the discretion to divide a motion if that is requested.
—I make that request, Mr President.
—I will certainly agree to it.

—Mr President, that might be the only nice thing I have done this week. I enjoy the feeling. In terms of the matters which have been raised in this debate, the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) would be well advised to seek further information from his Department in light of the apparent difference between what he has now told us and what Senator Reid has said she understands the position to be with respect to the employment of nutritionists. I am sure that the last thing the Minister wishes is to have to face us next week on the basis of misleading the Senate. I ask him, therefore, to examine that matter and seek further advice from the Department. The concerns Senator Reid has raised are ones which she has been examining for some time, and there appears to be some difference between the version the Minister has given us and the view that she has put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister in his response to this matter has confessed to and taken responsibility for what occurred. He has simply said that it is not a matter on which he should be censured. I wish to make a couple of points as to why we regard this matter as being of very great significance. The Minister's defence that in his answer he went beyond the question which was asked is not relevant to the matters we have raised. Ministers in this place often give answers to questions which have very little to do with the question asked. They use answers to questions, as Ministers have been quite open about this week, to make a statement about the Government's position on a particular matter. It therefore does not matter that a Minister has gone beyond answering the question that was put. The reliance of the Senate on the accuracy of all the information put before us is of significance, whatever the relationship of what was said in the answer to the question that was asked.

Senator Haines also raised a matter which is of very considerable significance and which I certainly did not raise in my original speech. The whole status of the parliamentary record has been changed by the amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act, to which she referred. It is a matter of only recent history that the courts have been entitled to look to Hansard to help them to understand and interpret the statutes which are passed by this Parliament. In those circumstances, the record itself has a legal significance which it did not have before. Therefore, the strict rules which have applied to changes become even more significant because they may affect not only argument in this place and in the community but also the interpretation and application of the laws which are passed by the Parliament.

The other point which should be made with respect to the Minister's explanation is that if in a department there is a view that an answer or even a supplementary answer is not completely representative of the truth, does not give all of the relevant information or in some way has the potential to mislead, quite clearly the procedure to follow is the one which the Minister himself followed in this case, that of giving a supplementary statement. Only yesterday Senator Gareth Evans explained and corrected an earlier answer, about which there is never any complaint in this place. The Minister's point about there having been a glitch is one which we reject. This is not a case in which there was some unintentional technical error. This is a case of the removal of words which clearly had a clear meaning and added considerably to the sense of the answer. In that sense we reject the Minister's defence that this was a mere technical point.

We believe that the principle is important. We believe that the passage of the two motions is important to send a message not to the Minister, who I am sure will be the most meticulous Minister in these matters henceforth, but to staff and to departments that these matters are regarded very seriously by the Parliament and that, therefore, the most serious action will be taken by the Parliament in such cases. I commend the motions to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As I pointed out to Senator Chaney, the Chair has the discretion to divide a motion. I have asked Hansard to provide me with an explanation as to how this matter occurred as soon as I leave the chamber.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill contains proposed amendments to six Acts.
the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952;
the Airports (Surface Traffic) Act 1960;
the Australian Centennial Roads Development Act 1988;
the Broadcasting Act 1942;
the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985; and
the Telecommunications Act 1975.

The Air Navigation (Charges) Act provides for landing charges in respect of aircraft using Commonwealth airports or other airports for which Commonwealth financial assistance is provided, and for penalties for late payment of those charges. There is provision in the Act for the refund or remission of these charges and penalties but currently no appeal mechanism against a decision to refuse a refund or remission. The amendment provided for in Part 2 of the Bill will provide an appropriate appeal mechanism. In the first instance, an affected person will be able to apply to the Secretary of the Department of Transport and Communications for a reconsideration of the decision. If the affected person is not satisfied after that review, he or she may then apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for further review.

The amendment of the Airports (Surface Traffic) Act is a purely technical amendment, which affects the repeal of section 16 of that Act. This follows advice to the Department of Transport and Communications from the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions that section 16 is now entirely unnecessary. Section 16 was included in the Act to prevent unmeritorious private prosecutions for offences against the Act. It is now superfluous as the Director of Public Prosecutions has the power to take over and discontinue any unwarranted private prosecutions.
The amendment to the Australian Centennial Roads Development Act 1988 honours an undertaking given by Senator Evans in the Senate on 21 December last year during debate on the Bill for that Act.

The Act provides for a program of financial assistance for land transport over the next 5 years. The funds are provided by a designated share of the excise on motor spirit and diesel fuel, known as the charge rate. The charge rate can be varied in a determination made by the Minister.

Some concern was expressed in that debate that a determination of the rate should be subject to Parliamentary scrutiny. The amendment meets this concern by providing that such a determination must be tabled in the Parliament, and is subject to disallowance.

The Bill also includes an amendment to the Broadcasting Act 1942 to enable the grant of limited broadcasting licences which involve transmissions from transponders on an AUSSAT satellite. This will correct an oversight in the scheme for limited licences which was introduced by the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Act 1988.

Limited licences allow streamlined licensing of a range of broadcasting services which, because of restrictions on duration, purpose, content or other aspects, do not raise the same public interest concerns as conventional broadcasting licences. For example, teletext services will be authorised under limited licences. As the legislation currently stands, only terrestrial transmissions can be authorised under a limited licence.

The provisions in this Bill will allow existing Remote Commercial Television Service licensees to seek limited licences to broadcast teletext services to remote area homesteads which have satellite receivers. It would also allow licensing, if and when appropriate, of other limited broadcasting services by satellite to remote homesteads.

The Bill also amends the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 to introduce a scheme for payment of the charges due under the Act by instalments. Senators may recall that Senator Evans, then Minister for Transport and Communications, made this promise to representatives of truck drivers during the blockade outside Yass last year. The amendment is a further indication of this Government doing what is within its means to reduce the impediments to efficiency in the long distance road transport industry and to alleviate the financial burden carried by independent owner-drivers in the industry.
The Bill also amends the Interstate Road Transport Act to clarify the validity of regulations which are now in place for the enforcement of vehicle and trailer mass limits.

The amendments to the Telecommunications Act in Part 7 of the Act aim to validate a number of routine zonal and telex changes which had been inadvertently implemented by Telecom without authorisation in appropriate By-laws. These errors were first detected by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in early 1988.

The Senate Committee which includes Honourable Senators Opposite, Senators Stone, Bishop and Patterson, picked up some errors in a number of Telecom by-law amendments in early 1988. The errors date back to May 1980.
As a result, Telecom was asked by the Committee to investigate the extent of the problem and to seek advice from the Attorney-General's Department on an appropriate remedy.

Subsequent advice from the Attorney-General's Department indicated that the only way of rectifying the errors was through validating legislation and that this legislation would need to be retrospective.

When this advice was conveyed to the Committee it asked that validating legislation be introduced as soon as possible and was reluctant to allow any Telecom by-laws until a commitment was given that corrective action would be taken.
This commitment was given by the former Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support and the Telecommunications part of this Bill is a fulfilment of that undertaking.
The Bill enables Telecom to make by-laws to correct the errors. These by-laws will be subject to Committee scrutiny before coming into force.

Routine changes to Telecom's zoning arrangements typically arise when obsolete exchanges are replaced by modern exchanges and the boundaries of charging zones, which relate to the location of exchanges, are consequently changed. Zoning determines charges and changes to zones require amendments to the by-laws.

Most zoning changes without by-law authorisation have not been zoning changes for the purpose of varying existing charges but have arisen as a result of additional zoning points in existing extended zones or additional exchanges in existing zones. These do not alter the call charges applicable.

In the remaining cases, changed call charging arrangements were put in place between particular exchanges or occurred as a result of the installation of new exchanges and the consequent transfer of customers from closed exchanges. Telecom is unable to identify the precise effect on individual customers. The new exchange arrangements resulted in higher charges in particular directions offset by lower charges in the other directions. The net result would depend on the individual customer's calling pattern.

Investigation of the above issues has also revealed errors in amendments to the Telecommunications (Telex Charging Areas) By-laws. These errors have arisen from clerical oversights in the listing of new exchanges and deletion of closed exchanges in the by-law amendments. They have not altered the charges applicable.

Under new legislation which will be introduced later this session, it is proposed that Telecom's zonal and charging arrangements be subject to simplified administrative arrangements which should ensure that such problems do not recur.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987[COGNATE BILLS:CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 April, on motion by Senator Tate:

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just getting to the point of rounding up my speech on clause 8 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. Regarding the question of defence exports I think that often people who are looking only at the financial aspect of exporting forget about the end use of the products they are promoting. I think that we should be considering the point of impact and the suffering of the ultimate receivers of these so-called defence exports which would more realistically be labelled as components of offensive weapons systems, as instruments of repression, whether items are in the form of hardware, training apparatus or military expertise.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely Australians can think of more creative and positive ways of improving our exports record. I do not believe that it is either morally acceptable or in our best interests strategically to be encouraging militarism in any way. Some of our exports could actually rebound on us. In raising these concerns about clause 8 of this Bill, I speak for hundreds of thousands of Australians. They include people who are totally opposed to any increase in the level of Australia's arms exports, people who see the urgency for international arms transfers to be curtailed, people who consider it morally abhorrent for Australia to be contributing in any way to the movement of arms around the globe, people who see trading in weapons as a massive social injustice and a wrong ordering of our priorities.

A former military man who was a five-star general and President of the United States of America, Dwight Eisenhower, once said words to this effect: Every missile that is tested, every gun that is fired, every weapon system that is deployed is a theft from the poor, the hungry and the oppressed of this world. That applies whether the weapons are actually used or not. The use of weapons results in a massive deflection of brainpower and financial resources from more socially useful pursuits. Let us encourage the arms manufacturers in Australia who look forward to these relaxations in export guidelines to be more positively creative, to dream up schemes for exporting pumps and windmills and appropriate energy and agricultural technology to our developing neighbour countries. It is time we started seriously the business of feeding the people instead of feeding the arms race.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be addressing that part of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 which deals with the relaxation in arms exports from Australia. I have just been reading an article by Frank Walker in the Sun-Herald of 21 August 1988 where this debate was foreshadowed. The article touched upon the hopeless protests of the Australian Labor Party's left wing members against the relaxation of arms trade controls. In the article John Langmore, a member of Parliament from Canberra, is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: We don't know if Australian-made weapons have been sold on to third countries despite a ban . . . Israel has very strong arms connections with South Africa and I want to know if Australian-made arms could end up in South Africa.
In the article Frank Walker concludes:

The few protests from Mr Langmore and his friends inside the Caucus room and Democrats and Nuclear Disarmament senators are likely to be drowned out by the big guns of the Labor, Liberal and National parties.

In this debate so far we have heard some of the big guns but the barrage has not really been all that impressive. We have not had a barrage from the Government yet. I suppose that Senator Button will provide that when he concludes for the Government.

It is extraordinary that no-one from the Government who supports the legislation has bothered to speak in the debate. Those who oppose it are not able to speak in the debate. Instead, the Government, as it did in the bases debate in November last year, has left its arguments on this matter to be carried by the Opposition, once again showing a bipartisan approach to defence matters. This happens with discomforting frequency on matters of defence. On 24 November, when the Government announced that it was going to renew the leases on the bases for 10 years, it left the rest of us to debate the issue and did not participate in the debate on the following day. A number of left wing members of the Government were left on the hop. They were not expecting that decision. When they went to the press about it they were extremely distressed, but it was closing the gate after the horse had bolted. There was little they could do about it at that stage.

When we debated this matter on a previous occasion we had a foretaste of the tenor of the arguments of the Government and the Opposition. We heard from the Government senators the same tired old arguments for expediency and observations that the world is not perfect. We are, it seems, already morally compromised so a little more compromise will not matter. But of course it does matter a great deal. Senator Newman was less circumspect. As well as the usual vicious and unwarranted personal attacks she actually presented the Government's case without frills or evasions-even though she is from the Opposition. This was a wonderful example of the bipartisan approach to defence matters that we have seen in the Senate time and time again. In her speech in the Senate on 8 March she referred to our `diabolical economic position'. I will read some of her speech into the record. She wanted to:

. . . draw attention to the fact that the effort that is put into trying to stop these legitimate exports is similar to the efforts that are being put towards the prevention of legitimate exports of paper pulp. The same sorts of groups are dead keen to see that Australia does not improve its balance of trade position with regard to wood pulp exports. There is a group of people in this country who have no recognition of our diabolical economic position and who would try to push their unrealistic economic views down our throats to the disadvantage of the nation.

I wonder to what lengths Senator Newman would go to sell off this country. The paper pulp comes from the forests of the New South Wales south coast. I do not want to address this matter today because we will be talking about it next week. At present the paper pulp comes from mature, old age forests in New South Wales which are an essential wildlife refuge. I, for one, do not mind being associated with the people who are trying to stop the rape of those forests, to turn them into wood pulp for a foreign company at the other end. Similarly, I do not mind being one of the group of people in this Senate who oppose an increase in Australian arms exports for a whole variety of reasons.

Senator Newman has not expressed any concern for a sustainable value added timber industry, as is the sensible approach to the forests of the south-east coast of New South Wales. It seems that she would be prepared to sell off all Australia's natural resources to make a quick buck, to right the diabolical economic position, as she calls it. I wonder whether economic considerations should take precedence over all other considerations, including ethical considerations. Certainly, on the basis of what Senator Newman says that is her position. It seems that it is the Government's position too.

Towards the end of Senator Newman's speech she referred to what is effectively an illegal arms transfer. She chafed at the fact that, during the Vietnam war, Sweden, which opposed the Vietnam war, refused to sell arms directly to Australia and we could get those arms only through what effectively amounted to an illegal arms transfer. Sweden sold the arms to England and England then passed them on to us. Midway through her speech she said:
We must do all we possibly can to see that never again are we in the hands of people who would defeat our war effort.

Them's fighting words, Senator Newman. Not even the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) these days talks about `war effort'. He is much more circumspect. He uses the word `defence' and tries to make it mean what it says. I remind Senator Newman that Vietnam was not only a moral disaster but also a military fiasco whose effects are still being felt today. Not just the Swedish people, but many countries and many people all around the world opposed that war. Certainly within Australia a massive number of people opposed Australia's involvement in the Vietnam war. They believed that we had no business being in Vietnam, that it was a civil war in which we should not have taken part.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has been proven by history to be totally incorrect.

—I do not agree with the honourable senator at all. Our involvement in it was a terrible mistake of history. However, surprisingly there is one point that Senator Newman raised that I agree with. She asked that the much heralded guidelines should be published quickly. I cannot understand why the guidelines are not before us today. All we have are the guidelines to the guidelines. So much effort has gone into explaining and reinterpreting the guidelines to the guidelines that I think we would all be better off if the Government had prepared the real thing before presenting this legislation to the chamber. At least then we would know what we were debating. The regulations will not be issued until after the legislation is passed. This is extraordinary. Once again we are debating this matter in the dark.

SPEECH.PARA: I find the choice of terms in the Defence Minister's news release of 14 June quite troubling and even sinister. It is the news release to which numerous honourable senators have referred, particularly Senator Vallentine and Senator Paul McLean. I would like to ask whether my apprehensions are well grounded. I think I know the answer to that question. In section 3, `Policy Constraints on Defence Exports', Minister Beazley writes this:

Under the new policy circumstances precluding defence exports are more tightly defined in terms of . . . violation of human rights with exports favoured where there is no reasonable risk of using the equipment against the citizens of a country with a dubious civil rights record.

May I ask what a reasonable risk is? Is it one where people are thrown into gaol for only one or two days, or is it one where one takes a bet and uses the rule of thumb? I find that sort of terminology very difficult to comprehend. When one puts it next to a reply by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, in the Senate on 24 May 1988 one becomes even more worried. In answer to a question on 24 May last year in relation to this matter Senator Ray said:
The Australian Government expressly reserves the right to prohibit the export of military goods to governments that seriously violate the human rights or constitutional rights of their citizens . . .

What does `seriously violate' mean? Is it okay to export military goods to countries which violate human rights a little, or which do not quite so seriously violate human rights? I would like to know exactly what is meant. The terms seem to be shifting, the definition is unclear and the way seems to be open for an unethical application of this part of the guidelines to the guidelines. If one looks at section 4 of the press release one will see that, apparently, these qualifications in relation to policy constraints actually mean something amounting to balance. Section 4 is called `Balancing Interests'. It states:

Under the old policy, a defence export application could be vetoed on general foreign policy grounds. Under the new policy, balanced consideration of Australian commercial defence and international interests is required.

The term `commercial' has primacy in the listing here. There is no mention at all of ethical considerations. The next section of the press release points out that commercial considerations have to be clearly outweighed for a sale to be vetoed:
Defence, strategic or foreign policy objections must be specific and must outweigh export benefits in a particular case.

Section 5, called `Clearer Responsibility', describes the exclusion of broader consultation on arms exports. The Minister for Defence will nearly always be the sole arbiter. The fast track 21-day decisions will accentuate the Minister's responsibilities. Under this legislation it is clear that the onus of proof will be on the Government if it wants to prevent exports rather than on the exporter to prove why goods should be sold, as in the past.
One of the little ironies of this legislation is that the Governor-General, Mr Bill Hayden, by his title nominally holds the keys to the arms export chest. Section 112 (1) of the Customs Act states:
The Governor-General may prohibit the export of goods from Australia.

He will be advised by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley. This is a situation, I imagine, that Mr Hayden might find somewhat galling if he is allowed to retain his judgment and moral scruples in his present position. Even if he were allowed to I doubt whether he would exercise his reserve powers even on this matter.

How true it is that we really appreciate people only when they are gone. Now we see Mr Hayden walking in an air of glory. Before, we noticed the suits and the unmistakable cadences of the Hayden voice and, more recently, the luxurious abandon of his proto-vice-regal jaunt. Bill Hayden used to know what a principle looked like. He knew what value to place on Australia's international reputation and he also had a good understanding of the economic realities of the international arms trade. I shall quote reports about Bill Hayden that have not been referred to earlier during this debate. An article in the Australian on 16 June last year states:

Mr Hayden said that despite the relaxation in controls he would continue to fight against inappropriate arms sales, as he had done in the past to prevent big sales to regional hot spots. ``But there must be morality, there must be principle,'' he said.
I would like to see Senator Button talk about that particular quote from Mr Hayden.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I missed what Senator Dunn said but I will look it up.

—I shall be glad to repeat it for Senator Button. I will give him a copy of Mr Hayden's quote. The 1986 report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence-Disarmament and Arms Control-quoted Mr Bill Hayden speaking at the University of Western Australia, Mr Hayden asserted:

SPEECH.PARA: we will be more active in the search for ways to reduce this flow of arms. Action will be taken aimed at stopping black market trade in arms. As I indicated in my speech to the UN General Assembly we consider these three goals are ideal subjects for consideration by the United Nations.

In answer to Mr Beazley's assertion that arms exports would more than double to $500m per annum Mr Hayden said that the additional sales would be marginal and `it's unfortunate the media hype has given the impression that we are going to get out to the centre of the arms bazaar hollering what our wares are'. What he said when asked if it were possible to increase sales to $500m, is reported as follows:
I think that can be done either if you are prepared to wait long enough or if we have hyper-inflation or if the Australian exchange rate skyrockets.
We won't be selling much else (if that happened) and I find it very doubtful if people will be wanting to pay a huge increase in costs.

We know what happened to poor Mr Hayden and his principles; he got rolled in Cabinet. Mr Beazley is an interesting Minister. He is one of Labor's `new men'. He is bluff; he is pragmatic; he has his sleeves rolled up; and he is not afraid to get his hands a bit dirty. Moral relativism is at the core of his position. Honourable senators should listen to his statement referring to Sweden which he made at the Just Defence Conference in 1986:
If you don't like how we now look at a defence exporter think what we might look like if we went into a Swedish defence industry mode.

That is exactly what worries me. Our hands could be much dirtier. The Department of Defence is effectively carving out an arms trade empire, perhaps to employ all those bureaucrats who used to shuffle papers backwards and forward under the system that Mr Cooksey criticised so scathingly. Is this change a Government decision or is Mr Beazley the creature of a subterranean Sir Humphrey in the bunkers of the Defence Department?

During my time in this place I have become much more aware of the independent agendas that are generated in particular departments out of their special interests and, in this case, international contacts. Under new guidelines the Department of Defence will be responsible for both generating the sales of arms and deciding whether those sales will fall within the guidelines. Some would argue that there is clearly a conflict of interest in this dual role.

There are some schizophrenic contradictions in Australia's arms trade position. It is not the only area of paradox, but on issues like nuclear deterrence the Government has the excuse that it will suffer repercussions if it deviates from our major ally's policy line. With arms exports Australia has a free choice. Mr Hayden was aware of these embarrassing contradictions when he complained in the United Nations:

I can't go to the United Nations special session on disarmament, as I did a fortnight ago in New York, (and) talk about our commitment in Australia . . . to work to try to cut back the arms trade . . . and then come back home and talk about a huge burst in the sale of conventional arms.

This quote should be repeated time and time again. It clearly shows up the hypocrisy of the present Government's position. No-one was placed in a more difficult position, as Senator McLean pointed out, than Mr Richard Butler, our former Ambassador for Disarmament. Among his other efforts he has been striving to persuade the United Nations to take up the issue of the conventional arms trade, especially its effect upon poverty stricken Third World countries. In a paper delivered at the defence conference at the Australian National University last December he commented upon the reception this initiative received. He said:

We have taken a new departure on the issue of international arms transfers and the international arms trade generally. The first thing that can be said of this stance is that it has been by no means popular. But the facts with respect to the impact of such trade on both security and economy are clear. We have steadfastly asserted that these facts need to be addressed by major arms exporters and importers, some of the latter of which are developing countries with major economic and financial problems, and by the international community generally. Opposition to this initiative including at the United Nations has been strong but at the current session of the General Assembly we succeeded for the first time in having a resolution adopted under which the Secretary-General would commence a process of examining and reporting to governments on the nature of and problems raised by international arms transfers.

With the information about the international arms trade that we have received since this matter was raised it is not hard to see why there was opposition. Mr Butler later enlarged on this theme, quoting Senator Evans addressing the General Assembly. Mr Butler said:

I have referred earlier to Australia's action in placing on the international agenda the issue of international arms transfers. This is an issue to which I believe we and the world community should give increasing attention.

The facts are multifarious and devastating. To use just two examples, between 1975 and 1985 when developing countries accumulated massive debt, presumably for development purposes, in fact 35 per cent of that debt was spent on the purchase of arms. At present, arms purchases by developing countries exceed the amount they receive in development assistance.
He went on:
Again, speaking at the current session of the General Assembly Foreign and Trade Minister Evans said:

``The quest for greater security through higher and higher levels of conventional arms is only too well know to us all. The international conference on disarmament and development provided ample evidence. It is a simple proposition that more arms do not equal greater security. They feed the appetite of instability and the coffers of those who choose to supply arms at levels that are well beyond those needed for self-defence.''

Senator Evans seems at least to pay lip service to the need for discrimination in this matter, but Mr Beazley unfortunately does not. Mr Butler continued but I will leave that quote since time is passing.

Already Australia has supplied a substantial quantity of materiel to Brazil, thus swelling our coffers while Brazil remains in a chronic state of financial distress. At least Senator Evans will not have to worry about soiling his digits with the arms trade, nor will he have the opportunity to apply his special competence in determining what an appropriate level for self-defence is. A close reading of the guidelines shows that the Department of Foreign Affairs is out in the cold and will be consulted only under special circumstances. It may be lightly consulted about policy guidance but, according to this document, the Minister for Defence is clearly responsible for developing and applying defence export policy. Interdepartmental consultation will be confined to denial of export permission or to particularly sensitive areas. I am opposed, of course, to the changes proposed by clause 8 of the legislation, but if I were given a choice-and it is not a palatable one-I would rather that Senator Evans and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade had a major or at least an equal say in the destination of any Australian produced military materials. After all, he is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

In an article in the Australian on 16 June last year Mr Hayden revealed that he had stopped some arms sales, some patrol boats to one country and mechanisms for personal booby traps to another. I doubt that these were the only sales stopped. By inference, the Minister for Defence and his Department were prepared for these sales to go through. I have serious doubts about the ability of the Department of Defence, and particularly the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, to be discriminating in the matter of arms exports. For example, the Department of Defence has had considerable involvement with the National Safety Council of Australia (NSCA). Indeed, many of the NSCA's employees were retired from the Australian defence forces. In an article by Wendy Bacon in the Sun-Herald of 26 March she describes very clearly the sort of involvement that the NSCA had with the Department of Defence. At the end of the article Mr Beazley is quoted as referring to the short time frame available to make a decision about why the NSCA got a contract above other people. He has once again imposed a difficulty upon himself by setting a 21-day period for decisions on arms export licences. He should take heed of his own experience in trying to decide major matters in a hurry.

I have no doubt that Mr Beazley will make decisions in relation to arms exports that he will regret, just as he is now regretting his involvement with the NSCA and another organisation called Parachutes Australia Pty Ltd, for all his attempts at justification. He wants to relax the arms exports controls, but is he aware of the shady deals that have almost been carried out by Mr Ed Crowther, an employee of Parachutes Australia? Mr Crowther used his position with Parachutes Australia Safety Equipment, a division of Parachutes Australia, to negotiate a deal with Colonel P.O. Wong in Fiji in 1987. He said that he could provide-and I read from the document-6,000 S.G. NATO assault rifles, available at a cost of US$450 each, to be ordered in quantities of 1,000 units only; 5,000 Beretta hand guns, US Army issue, at a cost of US$400 each; a certain number of Bell helicopters; and becoming available, S.G. 550 and S.G. 551 assault rifles straight from the factory, which are the very latest models. I would like Mr Beazley to tell us about these and to suggest where Mr Crowther thought he would get them from. If arms exports are going to be relaxed, will it make it easier for a Mr Crowther in future to export these rifles and helicopters?

I said when speaking to Senator Vallentine's motion in March that I cannot consider Australia's track record to be all that bad. However, I believe that these changes will open the way for Australia to become involved in some very dirty business. Australia has already sold to quite a number of countries and could become involved in the dirty tricks of the arms trade in which some of our allies have been involved. I read from an article by Frank Walker on 21 August last year:

The Iran-Iraq war has been a dream for the world's death merchants. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) found an incredible 27 countries sold weapons to the warring countries during the tragic conflict.

Not content with selling to one side, the US, the Soviet Union, China, France, Italy, Britain, East Germany, Switzerland, North Korea and Brazil all sold major weapons to both sides, despite several of them having bans.

It was thought all the gun-running to Iran from the US was being done illegally through third parties till the `Contragate' scandal revealed it was being done through a back room of the Pentagon with approval from the highest levels-
we are talking about our ally, of course-
While arms were falling off the back of US trucks to Iran, the US Government was telling Iraq how best to beat their enemy.

The new arms export conditions allow us to sell to all our allies without question. I ask: What is this going to get Australia involved in? I do not have time today to go into all the material on the dirty business of arms exports. We have to be very careful before we commit ourselves to what our allies are doing and before we surrender the sort of independence we would like to have and, I believe, should keep.

We should also question whether the aid we give to countries in the region is merely a precursor, a sort of show-room for future sales of arms, and whether in fact we really want to get involved in that rather than providing aid that is going to be much more useful internally to people of Third World countries. I would not want to be the one to cast the first stone, but I suggest that there are countries in our region whose human rights records are very poor. Even if Australia were to begin by selling these countries Mr Beazley's hydrographic equipment, once a sales relationship had been set up it would be very hard to exclude equipment that could be used to oppress a domestic population. We have to take heed of some very strong warnings on this subject.

More than a billion people in 60 countries are currently living under military rule. Nobody needs arms as much as a military dictatorship. The more proscriptions there are the more profitable the trade. We must bear this in mind when we look at the countries to which we are going to be selling arms. With all the military secrecy, it is difficult to know who we are selling what to. We need an open register which does not necessarily have to break industrial confidentiality. We must know what we are selling, to whom and in what quantities. There is an urgent necessity to be open about that. We are not really going to be able to compete on the market. Our First World allies already have the market fairly well sewn up. So the only markets that we are going to be able to sell to will be Third World markets. We must seriously question the ethical considerations of selling to countries which are spending much more on arms than on food and the development of domestic agriculture and industry.

The big budget items on our defence shopping list are the high-tech systems that we purchase from our friends. I do not suggest that all of these are unnecessary, but some of them certainly are. I would place in this category the FA18 fighters. The few crumbs we get from the offsets do little to reduce the net costs. We are still wasting money on totally inappropriate war games and the equipment necessary to turn out as a well-dressed player. Much of this expenditure would be better spent on equipment that is more clearly defensive.
