That, in accordance with standing order 364, Senator Dunn be required to table the document from which she was reading with regard to arms sales for Fiji.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Dunn will table the document from which she was reading.
—I have no objection to doing that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of a letter from the Law Council of Australia dated 5 April 1989 addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, which letter expresses its views on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
5 April 1989
Senator The Hon. J. N. Button
Minister for Industry, Technology
and Commerce
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (2) 1987 AND CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988
We refer to our previous correspondence and our major submissions on these two Bills.

The Law Council of Australia has learnt from a report in today's Australian Financial Review that the Bills were intended to be introduced into the Senate last night. We have become aware that they are now scheduled to be reintroduced today.

The Law Council wishes to emphasise in the strongest possible terms that in our view these Bills are fundamentally unsatisfactory. The Law Council remains strongly opposed to the basic provisions of both Bills.
We consider that the Bills represent bad law. In our view, they are likely to generate considerable disputes and litigation. They infringe civil liberties unnecessarily and unacceptably.

The Government's objective in preventing the avoidance of customs duty is commended. However, the Law Council believes that these Bills are not the correct means to achieve that objective. Our impression is that the effect of the Bills will be to increase, perhaps significantly, the cost to the community. Innocent importers may be hurt by the provisions of the Bills and the Australian Customs Service will gain unnecessarily wide and harsh powers of entry, search and seizure and the ability to impose penalty. (These matters are explained in detail in our submissions).

It has come to the Law Council's attention that changes have been made to the amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government (since the Law Council received copies of those amendments on 28 February). Some detailed concerns may be able to be met with such amendments, but the Law Council's fundamental concerns will not be able to be resolved by slight changes to this drafting.
If the Government does not see fit to withdraw the Bills from the Parliament, we suggest that they be considered by a specially constituted Senate Committee.
Yours sincerely
PETER LEVY
Secretary-General

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to a somewhat lengthy debate at the second reading stage of the Bills. I particularly thank Senator Coulter for his detailed review of the Government's proposed amendments to the customs package of Bills. I think it is best that we deal with some of the matters raised by honourable senators when the Government's proposed amendments are moved at the committee stage. I do not want to go through all those matters at this stage because it would waste the Senate's time. However, I want to make a few brief comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis mentioned the audit and verification of information powers in clause 22 of the 1987 Customs Bill and queried whether a power of entry without warrant on business premises proposed by new section 214aa of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) contravened article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That is a covenant which is concerned to provide protection against arbitrary or unlawful interferences in privacy. I assure Senator Lewis that during the drafting of the clauses, and on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, both were drafted specifically to remain consistent with the covenant's requirements. The advice on this aspect to the Government from the Attorney-General's Department dated 22 February 1988 was shown to the Opposition spokesman on housing, customs and small business, Mr Downer, during the pre-debate briefings on the Bill provided to Mr Downer on 27 and 28 February this year. I would be happy to provide a copy of that opinion to Senator Lewis. A lengthy process of consultation has taken place with all parties and the Opposition and that opinion was presented to Mr Downer at that time.

Regarding the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3), Senator Lewis, together with his coalition colleague Senator Boswell, sought an assurance that legislation lifting the sugar import embargo would not be brought forward before we received the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on the sugar industry. I can assure Senator Lewis and Senator Boswell that the Committee's report will be taken into consideration before any further assistance measures are proposed for the industry.

Senator Boswell was a member of that Committee. As the member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) said in the House, it was a great thing that Senator Boswell was a member of that Committee because, as a Queensland senator, it enabled him to see some sugarcane. That was probably the basis of some other remarks made by Senator Boswell in this chamber. During the debate on that Bill Senator Boswell launched a tirade against the Government, Ministers and various members of parliament over the proposed removal of the sugar embargo. However, I make the point that in the coalition's policy document called `New Directions', which I have read--

TALK.START.PARA: —Future Directions or `Future Diversions'.
—It is called Future Directions. Sometimes I have criticised that document and most members of the Opposition for being about the 1960s show-not new directions.

—I raise a point of order. Senator Button said that I was a member of the Senate Committee investigating sugar. I want to correct Senator Button. I am not a member of that Committee and never have been. I ask Senator Button to acknowledge that when he returns to his feet. He has been badly advised and I would not like the impression to go out into the community that--
—Order! I have given Senator Boswell some latitude to this point. Technically, it is not a point of order and I think that he has made his point.

—The honourable senator has made his point. It was one of the most breathless points I have heard made in the chamber. I accept his assurance on that matter and apologise. But I do not apologise for what I am about to say. Senator Boswell used the debate on the Bill to attack the Government about the sugar embargo. The coalition, in its document Future Directions, talks about a number of issues, which I will come to. However, the point I am trying to make is that, far from future directions, the Opposition in this country is really about the 1960s show. Senator Boswell is way ahead of the rest of them because he is really about the 1915 show as that is when most of this regulatory environment was put in place to protect the Australian sugar industry, at considerable cost to Australian consumers.
—You want to read Courtice's speech. He acknowledges that the sugar industry has subsidised domestic users for the last 15 years.
—Does he?
—You come in here not briefed properly. You have been caught out once and you are just about to put your foot in your mouth again.

—We do not normally reveal private exchanges between senators, but I did have Senator Boswell's office rung to say that I would speak on this matter. I invited him round here because I thought that it was courteous and fair to do so. The regulatory environment was established in 1915. Anybody with any doubts about Senator Boswell's position on this issue should not read his speech because it was one of the most confused speeches I have ever read. I think he was saying that removing the embargo could cost the sugar industry up to $30m.
—That is exactly what I said.

—That represents almost all of Australia's sugar sales. If removing the embargo could affect total Australian sales of sugar I do not think that anybody would do it. Senator Boswell opposes removing the embargo and replacing it with tariffs of 25 and 35 per cent. Those are higher than any tariffs in this country now, except those applying to the motor vehicle industry and the textile industry.
—Which goes down to 10 per cent.
—No, it does not.
—It reduces in 1992.
—Order! Senator Boswell, there are too many interjections.

—The May statement tariff cuts will benefit Australia's rural sector by between $350m and $450m. The National Farmers Federation estimates the benefits of the tariff cuts of May last year as roughly $2,400 per Australian farmer. Senator Boswell walks in here and says that that is all right and that it can happen to every industry except the sugar industry. He says there should be no changes to its level of protection; it must have an embargo to protect it. If any other country placed an embargo on Australian goods which we were exporting to it, Senator Boswell would be the first to object.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition's policy document says that the Liberal and National parties support the general current reduction in protection and will continue this process beyond 1992. I am grateful for their support on that issue. However, when it comes to any test of their bona fides as an opposition, such as deregulation of the wheat market, when they have to face up to a decision, they run away from it, just as they did throughout the 30 years of Liberal-Country Party coalition government. They ran away from all the issues concerning improved efficiency in Australian industries and reducing protection. They can sit on the opposition benches without having to make any hard decisions and just complain about us. However, when they are confronted with a couple of real issues, because they have to vote on Bills such as the wheat deregulation legislation, they run for cover. They do so because they are scared to confront the issues just as they were when they spent 30 years out of the last 39 in government.

In terms of the sugar industry, Senator Boswell has defied the spirit of the Future Directions policy which Mr Howard, his so-called Leader, announced not so long ago. The coalition's policy is that it supports phased down protection and will continue this process. Senator Boswell says that the embargo should not be removed. He does not even like it being replaced with a high tariff because he has to look after his so-called mates in the Queensland sugar industry. The more intelligent of them know that he is wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much support do you get up there?

—The honourable member for Hinkler has given Senator Boswell a bit of stick about this. He is a Labor member. He knows a bit about it. The coalition has a policy on deregulation. The sugar industry is the most regulated industry in Australia. Growers are even told where they have to grow sugar cane on their own land. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has estimated that 50 per cent more sugar could be produced in Queensland under a more appropriate regulatory environment than the one which presently exists. That represents a further $500m worth of sugar, at current prices. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics also states that $50m could be saved if more appropriate harvesting regulations were put in place, and that the uniform pricing formula costs the industry $130m a year. As I said earlier, it points out that most of those regulatory mechanisms date back to 1915. Senator Boswell is a clone of the Queensland Government, except at one stage last year when it changed Premiers and he did not quite know what to do, which person to support. We all know his position about the former Premier. We all know about those brown paper bags.
—That is scurrilous; withdraw it.

—Brown paper bags full of sugar, I am told, Senator. We all know about that. Senator Boswell is supporting the position of this Rump 1915 vintage political party. We have all sorts of debates in this place about what is wrong with this country. I will hazard a guess which I think will stand the test of any examination. What is wrong with this country is that for years and years we had governments which were not prepared to face up to the problems of real deregulation. They were not prepared to face up to the problems of reducing protection to soft and flabby industries. They were not prepared to face up to any of those problems. That was terrible. This Government now has the task of getting the country out of that mess. It is very difficult. But it is a dreadful, horrible shame to have to say that those opposite did not learn from all of those years. Even now, when they are confronted with an issue such as wheat deregulation or deregulating the sugar market, people like Senator Boswell represent the dreadful past of this country. The country was held back for years and years. Our competitive position internationally was reduced. The vigour and so on which should be associated with a country like ours was reduced.

—You are crying crocodile tears. What have you done about transport, shipping, waterside workers? You do not mind sticking the boot into the farmers, but you will never take on the waterside workers. You just put the boot into the farmers all the time.

—I remember Senator Boswell saying these things about everything that this Government took on. Over the last six years he has been shouting about all sorts of things that this Government would not take on. But in making those sorts of interjections he is saying, `I belong to a party which never took on anything. I can't understand how any political party would have the guts to take on these things, because we never did. I can't understand a government that has the guts to do these things'.
—Someone should take a point of order.

—He wants someone to take a point of order because he cannot stand the heat. He comes puffing into the kitchen and he cannot stand the heat, so he wants a point of order to be taken to protect him. What I said about guts is clearly illustrated by his request for Senator Lewis to take a point of order. The statement read as follows-
Amendments to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987
I move the Schedule of Amendments to be made to this Bill on behalf of the Government.

The Schedule of amendments proposes a total of 45 amendments to the Bill as originally introduced in this Chamber during the 1987 Budget Sittings of Parliament. While many of the amendments might properly be characterised as minor technical drafting changes, substantive changes are proposed to address many of the points raised in written submissions received by the Government on the Bill, and in meetings with interested parties during the consultations which have been undertaken on the Bill. I would like to take this opportunity to thank all those persons and organisations for their interest and helpful and constructive criticism during the consultative process. The Government believes the legislative package which is now proposed as a result of that process satisfies all the legitimate concerns which were raised during it.
The overall effect of the proposed Schedule of amendments which I have moved on behalf of the Government will reduce the Bill to two substantive elements only:
(i) the redraft of Division 2 of Part VIII of the Customs Act 1901, relating to the valuation of imported goods (Clause 12 of the Bill); and

(ii) the audit and verification of information powers of officers of Customs and the complimentary provision relating to the requirement to keep commercial documents (Clauses 6, 22 and 25 respectively of the Bill).
I shall discuss the proposed amendments to these parts of the Bill shortly.

The remaining elements of this Bill have either been transferred to the companion Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 (which will be discussed following the debate on this Bill) or are not to be proceeded with. In particular, the proposed administrative penalty regime and the offence provision for the making of a false or misleading statement (Clauses 26 and 24 respectively) have been transferred to the 1988 Customs Bill by amendments 41 and 37. This has been done so that the complete package of proposed penal provisions for the making of a false or misleading statement, including the removal of forfeiture of one's goods as a sanction for such a statement, is presented in the one Bill. I will discuss this package in more detail in the Committee stages of the 1988 Customs Bill.

Another change to the Bill, proposed in amendment 27, is the removal of Clause 16 of the Bill, which proposes an increase to three years of the current twelve months time limit for the recovery of short-paid duty.

The Government has accepted the view expressed by many in the Community that in the interests of equity there should be symmetry between the time within which a person may apply for a refund, rebate or remission of customs duty, and the period of time within which Customs may recover duty short-paid. Given the overwhelming preference for the retention of the current twelve month time period for each circumstance the Government has decided not to proceed with the existing Clause 16.

Turning now to the amendments to the two remaining substantive elements of the Bill, let me first deal with the proposed Clause 12 (Valuation Division) amendments. It should be recalled that the focus of the Valuation Clause in the Bill was the rearrangement of the existing valuation Division of the Act, to not only exhaustively enunciate all those matters which may or may not be included in customs value, and all the methods by which the customs value of goods might be determined, but also to eliminate some known duty minimisation and avoidance practices which artificially reduce the Customs value of imported goods, to the detriment of desired industry assistance levels and consequential revenue receipts.

It is acknowledged that the proposed valuation provisions are lengthy compared to other similar pieces of legislation. Indeed, many compare these provisions with the comparatively simple and straightforward GATT Valuation Agreement which they are intended to give effect to. However, the GATT Agreement, like all international treaties, is cast in the most general terms. To simply incorporate the Agreement by annexure, as some have suggested, would only invite lengthy and costly litigation to give the general terms of the treaty judicial meaning in Australia; further, such a course does not offer any guidance to, or provide any certainty for importers in valuing goods for Customs purposes.

The length too of the proposed Valuation Division redraft must be put into context. The proposed pages of legislation give effect to a complete valuation code, highlighting all the various methods by which the Australian Customs Service might determine the customs value of goods. Just over a third of those pages deal with valuation methods employed in less than 1% of all import transactions into Australia. Their inclusion in the proposed Valuation Division is for the purpose of completeness.

It should also be noted that in implementing an extensive valuation code, the Government has been mindful of its international obligations under the GATT. The Government is confident that the legislation proposed is consistent with the Agreement.

The Clause 12 amendments include amendments 5 to 10, to delete references to ``storage or handling costs'' from the definitions of ``Australian inland freight'', ``Australian inland insurance'', ``foreign inland freight'', and ``foreign inland insurance'', and include such costs only when they are incidental to the transportation of goods (which is consistent with article 8 (2) (b) of the GATT Valuation Agreement) by altering the definition of transportation (amendment No. 14). Additionally, amendment 16 removes proposed paragraph 154 (3) (f) from the legislation, under which it was proposed to deem persons to be related to each other if they were trustees or beneficiaries of the same trust on the grounds that that circumstance is not provided for under article 15 (4) of the GATT Valuation Agreement.
The Government has also considered comments made on the valuation provision by interested members of the Customs community.

Principal amongst these is the addition of a new subparagraph 154 (e) (iv) proposed by amendment 12, to ensure that certain royalties and licence fees do not become dutiable when such are paid or payable on the imported goods after their importation into Australia. This will remove an area of confusion in the wording contained in the existing Bill.

Furthermore, the definition of ``buying commission'' is amended to narrow the scope of the provision. In consultation with various industry groups and community organisations, the point was made that the proposed definition in section 155 of the Bill unnecessarily restricted buying agents. The amendment proposed in amendment 18 will now allow a buying agent to represent other parties in transactions unconnected with the import sale or the particular imported goods, without prejudicing the right to not include any commission payable to that agent in the customs value of the imported goods.

Finally, amendment 20 deletes proposed section 159, which would have required an importer to give a statement containing valuation information of a kind and in a form approved by the Comptroller. Following representations from industry, the Government has re-examined the need for such a statement and agreed not to proceed with it.
Other technical amendments to the valuation provisions of the Bill are discussed in detail in the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

The second remaining substantive element in the Bill, relating to the auditing of commercial documents (Clauses 6 and 22) and the obligation to keep commercial documents (Clause 25), has also been the subject of some amendment as a result of the consultations and representations on the respective Clauses.

With regard to the document retention obligation in Clause 25 of the Bill, a minor amendment is proposed in amendment No. 38 to clarify the position that the only documents which have to be kept for the purposes of the Customs Act 1901 are those commercial documents which will enable imported goods to be properly identified, and, in the case of goods entered for home consumption, properly valued or rated for duty. In addition the amendment will permit the keeping of certified copies of such documents in circumstances where the originals are required to be surrendered by force of law, or in the ordinary course of business.

With regard to the audit of information powers in Clauses 6 and 22 of the Bill, it should be recalled that those provisions were intended to facilitate the post-entry verification of information supplied to Customs as part of the Customs process of allowing the quick clearance of imported goods. Such a clearance system relies upon the integrity of the information supplied under it. So that the reliability of information can be checked however, without commercially unacceptable delays in the Customs processing of goods, the Government considers post-entry audits of information are necessary. The audit of information powers proposed in Clause 22 of this Bill should be viewed in this context; they are quite limited powers. Proposed Section 214aa confers a power of entry onto business premises only by consent, and only for the purpose of inspecting (not seizing) commercial documents believed to be on those premises to verify information supplied in connection with an import entry of goods. Entry onto such premises, where there is consent, is only permitted at reasonable times, and is only to be made where relevant information is reasonably believed to be contained on the premises, and access is only available to commercial documents relating to information supplied in connection with the particular import entry of the relevant goods.

Where entry is refused, or access to the relevant documents is not provided, or the premises on which it is reasonably believed relevant commercial documents are kept are residential premises, to which entry is not consented to, a search warrant must be applied for, which will empower a prescribed officer to enter and search the premises for the commercial documents relating to the particular entry of the goods concerned, and to inspect and make copies of (but not seize) any such documents found. The Government has acknowledged the concerns about the appropriateness of Justices of the Peace to grant such warrants, and is therefore proposing in Amendment No. 2 the deletion of the expanded definition of ``magistrate'' which would have accommodated this.

In addition, the Government is proposing in amendment No. 36 a facility to permit in circumstances of urgency an application for such a search warrant to be made to a Magistrate by radio, telephone or other means of communication. There is nothing untoward in this proposal.

Customs field audits and inspections of commercial documents might realistically have to be undertaken in parts of the country where chamber Magistrates are not readily available, and in situations of urgency to preclude the removal or falsification of commercial records. The number of safeguards contained in the provision to ensure against improper use, and in particular, the requirement that a judicially trained magistrate must be satisfied that the situation is one of urgency adequately ensure that this provision cannot be used indiscriminately or improperly. Additionally I have indicated a further amendment from the Government to pick up the suggestion from Senator Coulter in the second reading debate concerning the facility to contact the Magistrate for the purposes of verifying the issue of the warrant.

Finally it should be noted that amendment 1 proposes that all elements of the Bill, including this schedule of amendments, will commence on 1 July 1989. This prospective commencement date will enable both the importing community and the Customs adequate lead time to become acquainted with and prepare for the new regime.
Other technical amendments to the Bill are discussed in detail in the supplementary explanatory memorandum.
I commend the amendments to the Senate, and table the accompanying supplementary explanatory memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause 23a, proposed paragraph 243t (1) (a), leave out ``whether knowingly, recklessly or otherwise'', insert ``whether knowingly or recklessly''.

It has taken us quite some time to get down to Government amendment No. 11 to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. As this is the first chance I have had to speak in committee, there are one or two things I would like to say. Firstly, I want to correct something I said during my speech on the second reading. I inadvertently referred to new clause 243u at one stage-not repeatedly, as Senator Coulter kept interjecting-when I should have referred to clause 243v. I did so when I was addressing the new option, which provides that where the owner of goods is uncertain whether particular information included in a statement made in respect of those goods might be regarded as false or misleading, he may set out the reasons for the uncertainty at the time of the lodgment and no penalty shall be imposed under section 243.

I then went on to detail my belief that section 243 still raised difficulties. The context of my criticism would make it quite clear to any person reading the Bills at the time that I was in fact referring to new section 243v and not 243u. As Senator Coulter was at great pains to point out my error, I ask that it be noted that I was referring to section 243v when dealing with this particular difficulty for importers.

Secondly, I wish to give praise to the departmental officers and in particular Mr Ken McInnes, the legal adviser to the Australian Customs Service. When I was responsible for this portfolio some 16 months ago, when the Government was introducing this legislation, he gave me great assistance by explaining what was intended and the particular clauses of the Bills, all of which are very complex. He has briefed my colleague Mr Alexander Downer, who is now the Opposition's spokesperson on customs legislation. Again this morning when I asked him what was, to me, a complicated question he was able to explain easily, in simple terms, the nature of the proposals so that I was readily able to understand what had at first sight appeared to present some difficulty.

I now refer to the provisions of sections 234, 243t and 243u. Under section 234 the court will be able to impose penalties when a person knowingly or recklessly makes a statement to an officer that is false or misleading in a material particular, or omits from a statement made to an officer any matter or thing without which the statement is misleading in a material particular. It is right and proper that that should come before a court of law.

But in addition the Government is introducing section 243t, which enables the Comptroller-General of Customs to impose a penalty. I have some difficulties about the Comptroller imposing a penalty which is in the nature of a fine. Under the Australian system, as adopted to date, in effect penalties of this nature for making false statements have been imposed by courts of law. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills draws to the attention of the Senate and all honourable senators the fact that, in addition to the legal penalties imposed in a court, penalties are to be imposed by the Comptroller. Section 243t provides that where a person, whether knowingly, recklessly or otherwise, makes a statement to an officer that is false or misleading in a material particular, or omits from a statement made to an officer any matter or thing without which the statement is misleading in a material particular, then the Comptroller may impose a penalty. Instead of repeating those words in detail, I shall in future just talk about people making a false or misleading statement. What then happens is that the Comptroller may:

. . . by notice in writing, require the owner of the goods . . . to pay, within a period of 90 days after service of the notice, a penalty equal to twice the amount of excess, or a penalty of $20, whichever is the greater.

The insertion in that clause of a specific penalty of $20 gives one the impression that it is not a matter of major concern. But the customs agents have assured the Opposition parties that in truth a penalty equal to twice the amount of the excess could prove to be tens of thousands of dollars. So the Comptroller really has been given extraordinarily wide powers administratively to impose a penalty on a person who makes a false or misleading statement in certain circumstances. Although, thanks to all the delays and representations that have been made during the term of the delays, there is now in the Bill provision for the remission of penalties and a provision that section 243t is not to apply in certain circumstances, the penalty being imposed is substantial.

What really disturbs the Opposition, what has disturbed the customs agents and what has disturbed the Law Council of Australia, a body that should certainly be listened to by parliaments, is that a person really has no defence to this penalty if he unfortunately has made a simple mistake. That is the matter that causes us greatest distress. Section 243t specifically provides:
. . . a person, whether knowingly-
it would be not unreasonable for a penalty to be applied if he knowingly did it-
or recklessly . . .

Again, I suppose that if it could be established that he did it recklessly it may not be unreasonable for a penalty to be imposed. The Government has then added to the clause the words `or otherwise', which means that it is an offence in any circumstance, whether committed knowingly, recklessly or otherwise. In other words, it does not matter how the mistake happens; if it is made, the Comptroller, not a court of law, may impose a penalty equal to twice the amount of the excess, which we understand could amount to tens of thousands of dollars. I put it to the Government that that is unreasonable. The Government has rejected that assertion. The Australian Democrats could amend the legislation by supporting our amendment. Without our amendment, the clause is totally unreasonable, because it ensures that a person has no way of avoiding the penalty if he makes a mistake.

This morning the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, said that officers of his Department had made a mistake in altering the Hansard. He said that was not his fault. In that case, a Minister of the Crown was prepared to admit that a mistake had been made. Anyone can make a mistake. Yet here we have a case of the Government saying that the Comptroller may impose a penalty on someone who makes a mistake. It is then completely within the Comptroller's power to remit the penalty, or otherwise. The Government might say that the case could go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for its consideration, but I put it that that is not an adequate defence and that the words `or otherwise' should be deleted from the proposal. That is the purpose of my amendment. If those words were deleted, the section would then apply to a person who knowingly or recklessly made a false or misleading statement. I put it to the Government and to the Australian Democrats that that is a very reasonable amendment and that it should be carried by this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not support the amendment for two quite clear reasons. First, to exclude the words `or otherwise' would give two sections within the one Act which carry different penalties for precisely the same offence, namely, to do something knowingly or recklessly. That would be a peculiar result to achieve with that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leaving that aside and comparing section 234 and 243t and the other sections that qualify 243t, it is quite clear that 234 is aimed at serious offences because it is those offences which are committed knowingly or recklessly. Clearly, they require a much higher level of proof in the establishment of the offence. As a scientist, I do not know how one would prove that someone did something knowingly. It is clearly a legal definition, but I do not know how that could be established.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you think they establish in a murder case that a person knowingly murdered and desired to murder?

—Certainly that simply highlights the difference between proof in a scientific sense and proof in a legal sense. They are quite different. `Recklessly' in both senses is a heavily qualified term and will depend upon a range of conditions being met. People will have different opinions as to whether something is reckless or not. Again, the level of proof required to establish an offence under section 234 is of a much higher order than that which is required under 243t. Correspondingly, the penalty is much higher. It is $5,000 and-I stress `and'-twice the amount of the duty payable. Senator Bishop, in speaking to this measure yesterday, asserted that penalties under 243t could be higher than under 234. I find great difficulty in seeing how that could be the case, because in the one instance the penalty is twice the amount of the duty payable and in the other it is twice the amount of the difference between the duty that was paid and the duty that should have been paid.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 243t seeks to set in place a graded range of offences which go all the way from the most trivial mistake through to an error which borders on, but is not able to be established under, section 234. As I pointed out in debate on the second reading, it seems that customs agents, in particular, are setting themselves up as professional people and offering ostensibly a competent, informed service to the public. One therefore expects a high level of care. Certainly any other person in professional work-I think I mentioned doctors, lawyers and so on-is not exempt from penalty if he makes a mistake. The penalty certainly could be high in the case of an offence which involved the importation of a large value of goods, but correspondingly it is fair to say that if tens of thousands or hundreds of thousands of dollars were involved in that importation-and the penalty could be as high as that-one would expect that the agent concerned would exercise an appropriately greater level of care.

It should be stressed again that the provisions of 243v clearly allow a person who is genuinely uncertain to certify that he is uncertain, in which case no penalty shall apply. In conclusion, I simply draw attention to the provisions within section 243t itself: if a penalty is set which is considered to be unfair there are provisions for appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I suppose as a backing for that, if in relation to an honest mistake one were to detect that a comptroller or an officer working in that Department was applying penalties in any sense arbitrarily, there would always be an appeal mechanism to the Ombudsman. It certainly seems to the Australian Democrats that in moving these further amendments the Government has sought to satisfy the legitimate concerns which were expressed in relation to the original Bill. In view of the large amount of potential duty which can be avoided under these circumstances, we believe that the provisions of sections 234 and 243, with their qualifying subsections, are quite legitimate to be included in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because Senator Coulter has canvassed the issues. The distinction between the 243t provision and section 234 is simply that under section 234 the Australian Customs Service must be able to prove, on a criminal onus, that the person either knowingly or recklessly made a false or misleading statement. In the other section the use of the expression `or otherwise', which Senator Lewis's colleague, the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), has queried, is quite deliberately designed to catch all statements that are false or misleading in a material particular resulting in short payment or underpayment of duty. The provision is designed to catch somebody who knowingly, willingly, inadvertently, or in any circumstance--
—By mistake.
—By mistake-transposes a decimal point so that he may pay some hundreds of thousands of dollars less duty than is appropriate.
—We might say that if he would pay even more it would still be a mistake.

—Right. There are some good public policy reasons for this approach. The Customs Service has now adopted the greenline system of processing import entries. That means that in 90 per cent of cases Customs will rely on the information provided by the importer, giving the importer quicker access to the goods. It is really a system of trust, not only in terms of honesty but also in terms of accuracy. It is an honour system. Last year roughly $26m in revenue was lost or potentially lost because, for one reason or another, misleading entries were made. If that happens, government revenue is reduced. That is an important public policy point. But in some ways the more significant fairness point is that other importers competing in the same market who have paid the lawful amount and got their entries correct are prejudiced in the marketplace by the conduct of the person who is slack, dishonest, careless or inadvertent.

SPEECH.PARA: They are the essential public policy reasons for arriving at this conclusion. I understand in a conceptual sense the argument which has been put by Senator Lewis, but the circumstances of this situation are very different. That is why the deterrents have been proposed in the form that they have.

I make the point that the Comptroller-General's decision to impose a section 243t penalty is discretionary. He does not have to do it. Secondly, any person filling in his entries who is uncertain about the accuracy of the information he is giving can write that on the form. He will then not be in any sense liable to a penalty even though it is discretionary in the hands of the Comptroller-General. Thirdly, the penalty duty demand is effectively stayed where there is a dispute as to the amount of duty payable on the goods. Finally, any decision by the Comptroller-General not to remit in full the section 243t penalty may be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

This is a case of a clash between the desire for efficiency and uniformity in terms of all users of the system and a desire for some principle of general application but not of application in these circumstances as a matter of public policy. The Government thinks this process as set out in the Bill is important and does not accept the amendment.
