TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer seen Paddy McGuinness's article in yesterday's Australian newspaper in which Mr McGuinness advocates a shift in Australia's tax mix away from income tax towards a consumption tax? Does the Government accept the argument that `it is complex and difficult' to evade consumption taxes? Further, does the Government accept the argument that this provides a compelling case for shifting Australia's tax mix?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember that probably more than 10 years ago I wrote a letter to the National Times in reply to an article Paddy McGuinness had written which contained a rather serious arithmetic error. Mr McGuinness acknowledged, when the letter was published, that he had made an error and attributed it to `non-recurring seasonal factors'. That was just after Christmas. The article that he published this week was, presumably, written just after Easter. I do not know whether it also should be attributed to non-recurring seasonal factors.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the article. It points out-quite correctly, of course-that the introduction of the tax file number arrangements will make another major advance in combating the evasion of income tax. Mr McGuinness wrote:

The only kind of work that will escape taxation in this manner will be cash payments of the kind that are very common, for example payments for casual house-cleaning, child-minding and other personal services.

That is absolutely correct. The article then starts to meander. It finally asserts that the major defect in the income tax system is that the most powerful pay the least, regardless of how high nominal tax rates are. He then goes on to say:

. . . the only answer to this, as well as to the ability of those in the black economy to escape payment of income tax altogether, is a consumption tax. Consumption taxes can be evaded, but it is complex and difficult to do so by comparison with income tax.

The truth is that in regard to the particular examples that Mr McGuinness cited-casual house-cleaning, child-minding and other personal services for which payments are made in cash-it is equally as easy to evade either a consumption tax or income tax if a person is inclined to do so. Since Mr McGuinness identifies that as the major area of likely continuing tax evasion, whether the tax system is primarily or overwhelmingly dependent upon consumption taxes or income tax will make no difference to those sorts of unreported payments which ought to be taxable but which are untaxed because they are not reported.

To a somewhat lesser extent, the same sorts of arguments apply to small retailers. Unless one assumes perfect honesty on their part, one cannot expect perfect compliance from small retailers, whether it be in regard to income tax or a type of value-added tax. Whatever the arguments are, on balance, for or against a greater or lesser reliance on consumption taxes or income tax, the points raised by Mr McGuinness contribute little, if anything, to the case for a heavier degree of reliance on consumption taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice and Minister representing the Attorney-General to his answer earlier this week to my question about the report of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) on Rothwells Ltd, when the Minister advised that the decision to publish the whole or part of the report is for the Ministerial Council. I refer also to reports in today's Australian newspaper that the NCSC has obtained a legal opinion, signed by three counsel, including a leading Melbourne silk, which advises that publication would not have the effect of prejudicing the defence of any person or persons who might be charged with an offence as a result of the report. I ask whether the Minister or the Attorney-General have received copies of these opinions obtained by the NCSC. If so, will the Minister table those opinions for the information of the Senate? Has the Commonwealth sought independent advice on this matter? If so, what was the thrust of that advice? What position is the Commonwealth Government taking in today's vote by the Ministerial Council on whether the report should be tabled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall Senator Chaney's question earlier this week. I indicated that the Ministerial Council would have the ultimate responsibility of determining, after proper deliberation, whether-and, if so, in what form-to publish the report, by tabling it in a parliamentary forum. The report into the debacle surrounding the collapse of Rothwells is of great interest to all of us.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney asked whether the Attorney-General has received the opinion sought, I think I said, from Mr Walker, QC, assisted by two juniors. I assume that he has received it. I have not received such an opinion. It does not fall within my portfolio responsibilities. No doubt the Attorney-General has obtained such an opinion in his capacity as a member of the Ministerial Council. The Attorney would be seeking the advice of the Department. I do not know whether he has sought independent advice from a Queen's Counsel outside the Government, but I could check on that matter.

Advice proffered to the Ministerial Council is a matter for the Ministerial Council to consider. It will make its final decision on the basis of the opinion from Walker, QC, and such other matters as it takes into account in determining whether the release of the whole or part of the report would prejudice the course of prosecution and fair trial of those who might be subject to any charges. Therefore, it is really not for the Attorney alone to give an undertaking-I certainly cannot do so on his behalf-to release opinions which are provided to the Ministerial Council, or connected with the deliberations of the Ministerial Council. That would be a matter for the Ministerial Council to decide. In other words, I cannot give an undertaking on behalf of the Ministerial Council to release opinions provided to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that I asked him what position the Commonwealth Government is taking in today's vote by the Ministerial Council. I ask him to address that part of the question. I also remind the Minister, by way of supplementary question, that it is clearly and very credibly being put about that the report contains material which could prove highly embarrassing, and possibly damaging, to the Western Australian Government. I ask the Minister whether he agrees that in those circumstances the public interest requires the Commonwealth and those Ministers who are not directly politically affected to look very carefully at the public interest in seeing the disclosure of matters which may go to the credit of a government. In those circumstances, I ask the Minister to consider, and to advise in response to this question, how the Parliament and how the public are supposed to be satisfied that this matter is getting a consideration from a public interest point of view if the Minister is not prepared to table some of the advice which has been offered, bearing in mind that it has been freely put about that the Council has received advice that the document should be tabled.

—I do not intend to reveal the position which the Federal Attorney-General is taking in discussions with his colleagues on the Ministerial Council in relation to the deliberations which are still to be concluded. The question of the protection of the public interest relates to the necessity to ensure the fair trial of those who might be charged. That is the principal concern of the Ministerial Council. The question of the embarrassment or otherwise of a particular government, whether it be the Western Australian Government or the Queensland Government, will not in any way outweigh that factor, which is the key factor. The way in which Senator Chaney might gain some satisfaction that this matter is being looked at in a completely objective way, only with a view to securing the fair trial of persons in mind, is for me to remind him as I have, I think, on almost every occasion, that the Ministerial Council includes Attorneys-General from all Australian jurisdictions-those which have the good fortune to be governed by Labor and those which have the fortune to be governed by the conservative parties. If one looks at the article in today's Australian to which Senator Chaney refers one will see it is claimed that the Tasmanian Liberal Government has obtained an opinion from a QC in Melbourne to the effect that the report should not be disclosed. I am quite unable to say whether that report is correct. I take refuge in the belief that the composition of the Ministerial Council will ensure that this matter will receive the most careful and impartial consideration.

—Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen the report in the International Herald Tribune of last Thursday that an `intensive race is under way in the Middle East to obtain a poor man's atom bomb'-a ballistic missile armed with a chemical warhead? Has the Minister also noted reported comments from the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) Director that by the year 2000 at least 15 developing countries will be producing their own ballistic missiles and that 20 countries may already be manufacturing chemical weapons? Does the Australian Government view these potential developments with great concern and, if so, what actions have we taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware, with the help of Senator Maguire, of the International Herald Tribune report to which he refers and also of the statement by CIA Director, William Webster, that by the year 2000 at least 15 developing countries will be producing their own ballistic missiles and that 20 countries may already be manufacturing chemical weapons-alarming figures as they are. The Australian Government views the spread of chemical weapons as a major security and humanitarian problem. We believe that the most effective solution to this problem is through the conclusion at the earliest possible date of negotiations presently proceeding in Geneva at the conference on disarmament for a comprehensive ban on chemical weapons.

ANSWER.PARA: In order to prepare the way for that treaty the Australian Government has been active in implementing a number of measures that will contribute to containing the spread of chemical weapons. They are only partial solutions and are in no way an adequate longer term substitute for a fully effective global ban. These measures include chairing the group known as the Australia Group of 20 nations which consults on the operation of export controls on the precursors of chemical weapons. During the past nine months or so we have launched a regional initiative to discuss in detail with our neighbours in South East Asia and the Pacific the threat posed by chemical weapons, how to avoid it and the implications for each of us of the chemical weapons convention. An important series of visits have taken place in this respect with officials of my Department and the Department of Defence in this exercise. Thirdly, the decision has been taken to initiate and host a major international conference here in Canberra in September this year to bring together governments and their chemical industries to establish a dialogue on how to avoid inadvertent diversion of industries' products to chemical weapons manufacture and generally to contribute to building regimes that will be necessary to make a universal chemical weapons convention effective.

I think all of us share the horror of chemical weapons that has become apparent in recent times through their use in the Middle East conflict. We share the alarm that has been articulated by Senator Maguire in reliance on information now readily available about the spread of not only the weapons but also the ballistic missiles to deliver them. It is a situation which is looming as perhaps the most significant immediate disarmament question with which the world's nations are presently obliged to grapple. Accordingly, it is appropriate that Australia has been able to play such a substantial and visible role which it will continue to play in trying to cope with this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I would like the Minister to explain why pensioners on comparatively low fixed incomes are allowed to suffer a substantial reduction in income when the Australian dollar rises and the Department of Social Security does not change the notional exchange rate for some time. If the Ministerial response to another member of parliament is any indication, the notional rate is set and varied `from time to time'. The response does not say what regularity there is in regard to those changes on the basis of movements in the daily on-demand buying rate for pounds sterling cheques available from the Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA). The notional rates are varied when the movement in the CBA rates are relatively substantial and would appear to be part of an underlying trend. As a consequence of this, pensioners often receive less actual Australian dollar income without a compensating increase in their pensions. Given the Government's capacity to produce all sorts of complicated legislation and regulations on all sorts of other things, is it not possible to implement a better system of dealing with the effects of exchange rate fluctuations on pensioners by assessing the actual dollar value of foreign sourced income when it is paid into a nominated bank account, or at the very least, introducing a system where underpayments can be restored to pensioners to ensure they are not disadvantaged by a periodic over-estimation of the value of their foreign income?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information for Senator Haines. I think the first point that should be made is that whereas we do have the capacity for detailed and intricate legislation, it does not necessarily always help. Foreign income must be converted to Australian dollars to calculate the rate of pension and fringe benefit entitlements. Senator Haines's question seems to refer to the 90,000 or so pensioners who receive sterling income. I am informed that the Department of Social Security (DSS) uses a notional exchange rate to calculate sterling income which is based on the CBA on-demand airmail buying rate over a period.
—What period?

—The CBA rate is monitored daily to assess trends. If the honourable senator lets me answer the question he will probably get an idea of the period. The notional rate is changed when it differs too much from the CBA--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The jackals on the other side of the House should be quiet for a few minutes so that Senator Haines can get an answer. The notional rate is changed when it differs too much from the CBA rate trend and the Department of Social Security automatically recalculates pension rates. There may be a delay of three to four weeks between the date when a new notional rate is approved and the pay day it comes into effect. The delay would be due to lead times requiring DSS processing mail times and bank processing. It should be noted that quite recently variations were made to the notional rate for the pay days of December 1988, 16 February 1989, 2 March 1989 and 16 March 1989. That indicates that there is a degree of flexibility in the system.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Haines's question referred to the delay in converting exchange rate variations to the notional rate. I think we should also note in respect to this that the effect of exchange rate variations works in two different directions. If the value of the Australian dollar rises its theoretical effect in terms of the income test is to reduce the value of foreign source income and thus increase entitlement. However, if the value of the dollar falls the effect is in reverse and the entitlement is reduced. Thus, the averaging effect of the notional rate used by the Department is to smooth out variations. The Department aims to ensure that over a period no pensioner is disadvantaged. Measures such as the retention of fringe benefits for three months also help to protect pensioners from the effects of exchange rate variations. Finally, the alternative methods proposed for calculating exchange rate variations have involved considerable--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why won't you at least read it with expression?
—I wish Senator Newman would shut up for five minutes.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister should be asked to withdraw.
—That is unparliamentary. The Minister will withdraw.
—Could I suggest that Senator Newman keep quiet for a few minutes? The alternative methods proposed--
—Order! I have asked the Minister to withdraw.

—I withdraw. The alternative methods proposed for calculating exchange rate variations have involved considerable inconveniences for pensioners and administrative difficulties. My final point is that there is a guarantee and any pensioner who believes that he or she is disadvantaged can take evidence to the Department for consideration.
—I ask the Minister to table the paper that he has been reading from so that we can check his elocution and most probably some of his spelling.
—That is a decision for the Minister to make.
—No, Mr President, I will not table it.

—I ask the Minister a supplementary question concerning the terms he used. What is the period over which the fluctuation is taken into account and the period used for calculating whether or not a pensioner is worse off? What did `too much' mean when the Minister referred to the Department assessing whether there had been too much of a loss to pensioners? What does the Department intend to do with regard to pensioners who can be four, five or more hundred dollars worse off over six months or so under the current system?

—I believe that, in answering the question, I have covered most of those issues. I have already said, as to the period, that the notional rate has changed, if it does in fact differ, and there is no specific time frame for that. If the difference is too much, then the rate is adjusted accordingly. As to the definition of `too much', I will get that information for Senator Haines. As regards the last part of the question, I have already said--
—You are the Minister.

—It might surprise Senator Hill that I am not the Minister for Social Security. As regards the third part of Senator Haines's question, there are two points: firstly, exchange rate variations do work both ways; and, secondly, if there are major discrepancies and people do feel as though they have been disadvantaged, they can take particular cases to the Department. I will provide for Senator Haines further information on the definition of `too much'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook. Can the Minister provide the Senate with evidence to support his statement in the chamber yesterday that `it is drawing a long bow indeed to identify what is a prospective development as influencing the greenhouse effect', the prospective development being a coal-fired power plant at Mount Lesueur in Western Australia? I ask the Minister whether he agrees that his assessment of the link between coal burning CO2 emissions and the greenhouse effect was blatantly contradicted on the same day by the Prime Minister, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: There was no doubt that burning fossil fuels like coal added to the problem . . . and the Government would not shy away from the implications this might have for Australia's mining industry . . .

Can the Minister explain the inconsistency between the Government signing the declaration of The Hague last month, designed to give political impetus to urgent efforts to counter greenhouse effects, the Prime Minister's statement I have just quoted, and his own dismissive treatment of a proposed coal mine and coal-fired power station at Mount Lesueur as just another States rights environmental issue? With reference to the Minister's statement yesterday that `this type of operation is entirely State based and is not something over which the Commonwealth has any powers', can the Minister explain why the use of fiscal policies and tax incentives are not available to the Commonwealth to influence energy efficiency, conservation and development inside State borders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine has quoted from my answer yesterday. I just happen to have the pink copies and have checked Senator Vallentine's quotes. They are consistent with what the pinks divulge.
—Is that the original pink?

—They are the original pinks. Senator Vallentine's question suffers from the fact that she is proselytising a cause and a point of view rather than looking objectively at the facts. Thus it is that Senator Vallentine can come to what is, frankly, a distorted view of this issue, simply because her concern to make her point overshadows her interest in finding out exactly what is the informational base about the greenhouse effect. In that context, it is indeed a bizarre question that Senator Vallentine has asked.

ANSWER.PARA: The first part of the question was whether it is drawing a long bow to identify the prospective development with respect to Mount Lesueur. I do not think that is a long bow at all. I am sorry, I do think that is a long bow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Delete whichever does not apply.

—I do think that she is drawing a long bow. This is a fundamental point about asking and answering questions in this place. Senator Vallentine asked me whether a prospective development would affect the greenhouse effect. Of course it will not. It will only have an impact on the greenhouse effect if the prospective development actually becomes a development. Senator Vallentine is asking me to agree that something on paper might have that effect. I am not going to agree to that, and it is right to say that that is a long bow.

ANSWER.PARA: I was then asked whether I am contradicting the Prime Minister. Of course I am not contradicting the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is absolutely right. In his typical, honest and blunt way, the Prime Minister is saying that coal-fired power generation has some contributory effect. That is true. The question, though, that I am being invited to assume is that it is the exclusive, major and whole effect. As I said yesterday in my answer to the question, CO2 emissions are half of the greenhouse gas emissions. The other half are spread across a range of other gases, including methane and chlorofluorocarbons. Of the CO2 emissions, coal is but a component of that. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, said yesterday that he believed the major cause of CO2 build-up was car exhaust emissions, which are from oil burning generation, not from coal burning generation. There is another view that one of the other significant causes is simply the world population explosion. The population of the globe is now heading towards six billion from about two billion 40 years ago. It is thought that the number of people just expiring is the cause of the build-up of CO2.

This issue is assisted considerably by getting the factual base right and being objective about what the causes are. A prospective coal mining and power generating operation in Western Australia is rightly called a long bow. It is not inconsistent with anything that we have said at The Hague. I still think it is inappropriate to use the levers of fiscal and tax incentives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to Senator Chaney's earlier question regarding the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) report on Rothwells Ltd and the Minister's answer that there are currently legal opinions that suggest that proceedings might be instituted against certain people. Does the Minister agree that it would be eminently possible--
—I did not say that.

—Well, that the report touches on such matters. Does the Minister agree that it would be possible to edit the report in such a way as not to prejudice legal proceedings that might be taken? Is it not the fact in any event that there are media reports suggesting that the report bears on actions of certain Ministers and others associated with Ministers in the Labor Government of Western Australia which carry no legal consequences for those Ministers but which could well create significant political embarrassment for them? In those circumstances, what possible reason is there for non-disclosure of those parts of the report? Will the Minister consider taking action to defer the report date of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, which is currently under such indecent pressure to report next Thursday, in order to enable the Committee to consider the public interest implications of the report on Rothwells? If the Minister will not, does he agree that, unless the Government is prepared to be more frank with the Senate and the general public about the public interest implications of this and other reports, there will be no conclusion that can be drawn other than that he is in the business of protecting his political mates in Western Australia?

—Despite all the bluster of Senator Alston, there is hardly anything I need add to the answers I gave yesterday and earlier today to Senator Chaney. I have indicated that I am not going to draw on media reports of what might or might not be the case. I have affirmed that the Ministerial Council is concerned only to protect the fair trial of those persons who might face charges. It is most important that their trial should not be prejudiced. It has been made very clear that the question of reported or supposed embarrassment of members of any government, whether that be Western Australia or Queensland, are not considerations. I have indicated that the very composition of the Ministerial Council gives me confidence to make the assertion that the matters will be considered very impartially. As the honourable senator indicated, it may be a question of an edited version rather than the whole of the report being made available. That will be one of the considerations of the Ministerial Council's deliberations in order to safeguard the fair trial of certain persons. That will be the only consideration in the minds of Council members. As to whether a joint committee of the Parliament should look at the matter, I believe that the Ministerial Council is vested with the proper responsibility, and it will soon be manifest that it has discharged that responsibility quite properly.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does it follow from that that the Minister takes the view that the Joint Select Committee has no interest in this matter and that the Government could not urge the Ministerial Council to cooperate with a request from the Committee for an opportunity to consider the report?

—Individual Committee members might have an interest, as other senators might, in the matters relating to the collapse of Rothwells. I think that we all have an interest in them. I am saying that I do not believe it is appropriate that a term of reference or an extension of the reporting date, which is what the honourable senator requested, be given to that Committee to consider those matters. I believe that the Joint Committee has been vested with a very onerous and difficult responsibility, which it has discharged over many months. If, as the honourable senator seems to suggest, it has reached a point where the Committee can put down a report by next Thursday, I believe the Senate and the Parliament would be indebted to it if it concluded its deliberations and made that report available.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of comments made by Mr Chris Northover, the Chairman of the Forest and Forest Products Industry Council (FAFPIC), as reported in this morning's press? Those comments were critical of the input of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) into the Government's decision on the Wesley Vale pulp mill. Have those comments been formally conveyed to the Minister? If so, does the Minister agree with them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article in the Australian. In fact, I have it in front of me. It makes a number of claims which are attributed to Mr Northover, who is Chairman of the Forest and Forest Products Industry Council, relating to CSIRO's handling of a report on Wesley Vale which was prepared for the Government and given to the Government shortly prior to the time we reached a decision on this matter. It is true that Mr Northover is Chairman of FAFPIC. If what is reported in the press is correct, I suspect that the views expressed were Mr Northover's personal views. It is true that the Australian Manufacturing Council discussed the Wesley Vale proposal at its last meeting and agreed that a submission should be prepared for presentation to the Government on the important lessons that could be learnt from the Wesley Vale process. I believe that that report is now being prepared.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in contradiction to Mr Northover's view, I should say that in discussions I have had with companies in the forest industry since the release of the CSIRO report, they have made it clear that in their view, given the time constraints available and the wide range of issues, the CSIRO produced a balanced report and played a constructive role in the discussion. That is a view which I also expressed to a large meeting of the CSIRO Staff Association. I do not resile from that view at all. I think that it was a comprehensive and balanced report, given the somewhat difficult circumstances in which it was prepared. In that report, CSIRO had many good things to say about the Wesley Vale proposal as well as criticisms. I believe that the report would withstand critical analysis by any independent observer. While understanding Mr Northover's concerns, I do not agree with the expression of his concerns in so far as they relate to a very critical analysis of CSIRO's role in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Justice a very serious question with implications for Australia-Indonesia relations, and I trust that he will not treat the matter in the flippant manner demonstrated by his colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, on Wednesday. Can the Minister advise whether the Australian Federal Police (AFP) are investigating a bomb threat on a flight of the official Indonesian Merpati Airlines from Darwin to Timor on Wednesday? Were all passengers and luggage thoroughly checked by security following a fracas in the Darwin Airport terminal involving known rebel Fretilin sympathisers? Will the Minister ascertain whether there are any connections between the bomb threat incident, the airport troublemakers and Fretilin or Lafaek members who, with the Australian Labor Party (ALP), were joint hosts of a so-called community function for the Prime Minister on Saturday, 1 April? Are the Australian Federal Police concerned about an obvious and dangerous security risk to the Prime Minister and other invited guests to the function of 1 April?
—I do take such questions seriously, so seriously that I will seek advice from the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police and give an answer at an appropriate time.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am pleased to note that the Minister is prepared to take further investigations and inquiries on board. In that regard I ask him to ascertain whether the leader of Fretilin in Darwin and a member of an anti-Indonesian solidarity group, Mr Jose Gusmao, presented a letter on behalf of Fretilin to the Prime Minister at the ALP function. Was Mr Gusmao also involved in the airport fracas? Is the--

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Supplementary questions must be directed to the answer a Minister has given. Senator Tambling is asking a separate question. It was meant as an ambush in case he did get an answer. He did not get one, so he should have dropped his supplementary.
—I believe that it is a completely separate question, especially when the Minister did not reply to the first question, except to say that he would get a reply.

—In his answer the Minister indicated that he would take the matter on board as an inquiry. In doing so, I believe that the issues I seek to raise in the supplementary question are just as important to that inquiry and I wish to pursue them. I have one further small question.
—Order! It is a separate question; it is not a supplementary. The honourable senator should have asked it as part of his original question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, although it may be more appropriate to direct it to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of the difficulties and, therefore, delays that many low paid workers experienced in obtaining a 4 per cent increase under the second tier arrangements in the last round of wage negotiations, in many cases because they were in efficient industries and had very little to trade off? Is it a fact that those workers experienced a lowering in their standard of living by comparison with others in cost-plus industries who were less efficient and had more to trade off more readily? In addition, is the Minister aware of the figures that are available to the Government, including those of its own Institute of Family Studies, which show that low paid workers pay a greater percentage of their wages in tax now than they have for many years, and perhaps a greater percentage than they have ever paid? Is it true, as it seems to be from published reports, that the Government opposes proposals for a lift in the minimum wage of low paid workers? Will the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will agree to a new wages system in the restructuring discussions which will not disadvantage those workers who are in efficient industries and have nothing to restructure or trade off?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concede that Senator Harradine's question has a serious purpose, and I will try to answer that, but I do not necessarily accept that on the basis of the 4 per cent wage round, those industries which were not able to give up particular benefits and so on were necessarily efficient. I do not want to enter into the efficiency or otherwise argument. The point of the question is really about lower paid workers. Whether they are in efficient or inefficient industries does not seem to me to matter very much. With regard to that part of the question, the Government has announced two intentions. Firstly, it will look at the tax question with a view to producing greater equity in the tax system. An announcement will be made about that next week. Secondly, the Government, in a submission to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, has put a position which agrees to wage increases on an award restructuring efficiency basis which will take place over a period.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is also in the process of negotiations with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) about what is called the supplementary payments issue. This relates to that part of the honourable senator's question concerning low paid workers. In any Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decision, hopefully, as a result of agreement between the parties, they will be the beneficiaries of supplementary payments in addition to any other net benefits they receive from the revised taxation arrangements and award restructuring. Senator Harradine used the term `lift in the minimum wage'. The jargon about this issue changes from time to time, but the supplementary payments issue is designed to deal with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your view on supplementary payments?

—It is a matter which is subject to current negotiations, as are occurring today, with the ACTU. Certainly, the Government's view is that there should be supplementary payments for low paid workers, but not of the order that has been mooted in the press, allegedly on behalf of some union officials. It is a matter of arriving at an appropriate balance and doing the best we can for lower paid workers.

—The Minister representing the Prime Minister will be aware of both the Prime Minister's promise during the Western Australian election that interest rates would soon fall and of the fact that money is now being offered at interest rates of 19.5 and 20 per cent. Is the Government aware of the misery to which it is a party when people have to pay these rates? How high will the Government permit long term interest rates to go before it is satisfied with the havoc it is wreaking? How does the Government intend to remedy the situation and to redeem the quite specific promise of the Prime Minister to the people of Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume talked about the quite specific promise of the Prime Minister in Western Australia prior to the Western Australian election. He did not quote anything that the Prime Minister said. My recollection of what he said was that he hoped that interest rates would come down by the end of the year.
—He changed his `pinks'.

—Senator Stone is making an impassioned interjection. Such is the disarray in the coalition that I cannot even hear what he is saying. His colleagues will not let me hear it. That is how they treat the National Party, Senator. Will the honourable senator repeat his interjection, please?
—The Prime Minister has simply corrected the `pinks'.

—I see; a parochial joke. The substance of Senator Peter Baume's question, of course, goes to a very important issue. In terms of the alleged promise made by the Prime Minister, I query whether the honourable senator's view, as expressed in his question, is correct. I would like to see it documented, and not on the basis of some suburban newspaper article in New South Wales. No government wants to maintain interest rates at high levels any longer than it has to. But there has been a very high growth rate in the Australian economy and that high growth rate must be dampened down.
—No. It is a high growth rate in demand.

—No, Senator. That growth rate has to be dampened down. The Government has said on a number of occasions that it will have a policy of reducing interest rates as soon as possible. The major responsibility of the Government is to reduce that level of demand at present. We will maintain a position on that until we can adopt a policy which would be much more suitable to us and to the Australian people. Those rates will have to remain tight until there is a sustainable level of demand.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Peter Baume also asked whether the Government appreciated the difficulties being encountered by some people with mortgages at mortgage market rates. Yes, we do and, of course, there are others who are affected by high interest rates. The Government understands that. But in terms of the policy which has to be followed at present, we can say no more than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice to the Cash Transaction Reports Act. Can the Minister indicate to the Senate what impact that Act has had on the fight against criminal activity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe this is a matter of great interest to honourable senators who engaged in a very vigorous debate on the merits of the Cash Transaction Reports Bill. I believe they would be interested to know what some of the results have been to date. When I visited the Brisbane office of the Australian Federal Police in February, before the start of the parliamentary session, I was informed that in late 1988 the AFP had become aware of irregularities with a bank account held with a branch of the Westpac Banking Corporation in Brisbane. Investigations revealed that an individual claiming to be unemployed had opened the account and that between May and September 1988 approximately half a million dollars had been deposited and transferred through the account by telegraphic transfer to an account with a foreign bank in Singapore. I am further informed that inquiries indicated that, although in different names, the two accounts were held by the same person. Undoubtedly, honourable senators will be aware of the claims made that, for example, at the last State election in New South Wales the committee found that multiple voting appeared to have occurred in nearly all of the State's 109 electorates, especially in the State division of Balmain, where one voter was suspected of having voted at least 15 times.
Senator Schacht interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht should not get too anxious: we are about to deal with some of these voting irregularities. The question of the integrity of the roll and its relationship to enrolment by subdivision is important. Let me give an example from Labor Party sources of the importance of the electoral roll. Senator Richardson and our new colleague Senator Faulkner both had an interest in the Labor Party preselection for the State seat of Liverpool. One of the factors which determined whether people were entitled to vote in the preselection for the seat of Liverpool was whether they were on the electoral roll. Electoral rolls are important not only for the conduct of Commonwealth elections but for the conduct of internal political party ballots. If one looks at the Sun-Herald of 26 February 1989 one will see that a person who believed she was entitled to vote in the Liverpool preselection, Mr Violet Goulden, was reported in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Pensioner, Mrs Violet Goulden, a lifelong ALP supporter, is angry at the way her vote for Mr Lynch was declared invalid.
She said the reason for her disqualification was that she was not on the current electoral roll.

Mrs Goulden has produced evidence to show she made three attempts to notify the Electoral Commissioner of her change of address. As a result of all that, as honourable senators will know, Mr Lynch had the Liverpool preselection stolen from him. Senator Faulkner, as he is now, was asked some questions about this. On the AM program on 2 March Mr Faulkner, as he was then, said:

There is conclusive evidence that two people in the Liverpool preselection ballot have been denied a vote improperly. Someone has rewritten a branch boundaries map, so the branch boundary instead of going down the Hume highway goes down a cul-de-sac and through a park and conveniently writes two people out of the preselection.
The interviewer asked him:
Is there any doubt, in your mind, who won the preselection?
Senator Faulkner said:
Absolutely none. The preselection ballot was won fairly and squarely by Paul Lynch.
Question:
Who rorted it?
Answer:
I don't know who rorted it, except to say no individual rorted it, but I can best identify the New South Wales right-wing machine.

No wonder Senator Richardson hides his head in the papers he has in front of him. He is the expert in this matter. I simply make the point that it is important for a number of reasons that the electoral roll be kept fairly and squarely up to date.

There is one particular matter of some interest in terms of electoral enrolments which, after reading last year's annual report of the Australian Electoral Commission, I find quite fascinating. It relates to the extent to which variations occur over time between enrolments in the States. For instance, on 12 June 1987 in the State of Victoria there were 2,696,474 electors enrolled and on 24 June 1988 there were 2,678,015. In Queensland there were 1,706,902 enrolled on 12 June 1987 and 1,676,706 enrolled on 24 June 1988. These figures are important because they go to the question of whether a State should have a particular representation in the House of Representatives. What I found extraordinary and, frankly, almost unbelievable from a statistical point of view was that on 12 June 1987 the enrolment in the State of Tasmania was 300,463 and on 24 June 1988 it was 300,463. I must say I find it absolutely remarkable that in the course of a year and a week the electoral enrolment of that State did not vary by one vote one way or the other. It might be an interesting statistical anomaly but I find it somewhat curious.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well organised.
—Senator Richardson said it was well organised.

—I am not surprised. Senator Richardson knows a great deal about organising these things. The second point which arises in this legislation is that the second reading speech is actually quite misleading. The second reading speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides a fixed formula for the representation of Territories and new States in the Federal Parliament.

The Bill actually says absolutely nothing about representation of new States. The reason is that the Commonwealth Parliament cannot provide for the representation of new States until such time as the new State is admitted. That is simply a constitutional requirement. It is a piece of extraordinary sloppiness to be told that a Bill is going to provide for something and then find that the Bill does not provide for it.

The reason the Bill does not provide for it is that constitutionally it cannot. Frankly, if the Electoral Commission cannot do better than put into a second reading speech that something is going to be in a piece of legislation and then find that it is not in the piece of legislation, the Minister ought to be asking some questions in that regard. When we come to those particular sections I will have cause to make some comments about the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, report No. 1, of November 1985 entitled Determining the Entitlement of Federal Territories and New States to Representation in the Commonwealth Parliament and to indicate our support for the general thrust of those amendments, which, after all, very largely derive from the initiatives taken by the honourable member for Sturt in the other place, Mr Ian Wilson, who is from the same State as you, Mr Acting Deputy President. In discussion on the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1983, it was he who first suggested in a parliamentary and legislative form the way in which the representation of the Territories should be fixed by formula.

The next point to which I wish to refer is the question of voting entitlements for persons in prison. At present the Commonwealth Electoral Act provides in clause 93 subclause 8 (b) that a person who has been convicted and is under sentence for an offence punishable under the law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory by imprisonment for five years or longer is not entitled to have his name on the electoral roll and, consequently, not entitled to vote. This legislation provides that anybody who is in prison, except for the crime of treason-and I cannot recall whether there has ever been an imprisonment for treason in Australia, although I stand to be corrected-is now entitled to vote. When we come to the committee stage the Opposition will move for the deletion of this provision in order to return to the provision that anybody who is in prison for five years or more shall not be entitled to vote. If that amendment is not successful, the Opposition will in fact vote against the entire piece of legislation.

If one looks at the comments in Report No. 2 of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, entitled The Operation during the 1984 General Election of the 1983-84 Amendment to Commonwealth Electoral Legislation, one will see this matter dealt with at some length. We will come to that in the committee stage of the Bill. However, I should draw attention to the fact that the question of the restriction of the voting rights of prisoners was a majority recommendation made by the members of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats and that there was a dissenting report, on pages 218 and 219, submitted by the then Senator the Hon. Sir John Carrick, by the Hon. Michael MacKellar, MP, and Mr Charles Blunt, MP, in which the views of the coalition parties in opposition to this extension of voting rights to prisoners were clearly set out.

The Opposition will also be seeking to make amendments in this legislation to the question of the use of mobile booths in terms of paying visits to hospitals. At present the Act precludes a candidate from entering hospitals, special hospitals, nursing homes or similar institutions in order to canvass for votes once the writs for an election have been issued. We will move to delete that particular provision. In essence, what the Act says is that a person who is in hospital, special hospital, nursing home or similar institution shall not be subjected to any candidate entering that particular institution from the date of issue of the writs. We believe that there should be some reasonable restriction placed on people on, say, polling day or in the week leading up to polling day.

However, we do not believe that candidates in a fair and open democratic election should be denied the right to canvass inside hospitals, special hospital or nursing homes from the date on which the writs are issued. We think that that is an unnecessary, unfair and improper restriction on the rights of candidates to canvass for votes in important institutions, particularly since those persons are among those most likely not to have access to electoral information provided in any other form. They are the people, apart from prisoners, most likely to have no access to electoral information other than that supplied by the Electoral Commission from the date of the issue of the writs. Therefore, we will seek to amend that by omitting from the legislation the clause which brings about that prohibition.

We will also move an amendment dealing with the processes of redistribution and, in particular, the fact that a situation can arise in this country where a party can win a majority of the votes, and indeed a majority of the votes on a two-party preferred basis, and nevertheless find itself actually losing seats. At the last general election the Liberal and National parties combined 46.07 per cent of the vote on a national basis. The Australian Labor Party 45.83 per cent nationally. Nevertheless, as a result the coalition parties lost seats and the Labor Party gained seats. For example, in Western Australia at the last election, the two-party preferred vote was 52.2 per cent for the Liberal and National parties and 47.8 per cent for the Labor Party. But the Labor Party was able to secure a greater number of seats. Therefore, we will move an amendment requiring that greater steps be taken in terms of Commonwealth legislation to ensure that a party winning in excess of 50 per cent of the votes is entitled to more than 50 per cent of the seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—If Senator Schacht cares to look at the Opposition's amendments, he will see the methodology which we propose in that respect. We will be able to debate that in some detail and with the necessary attention to the technicalities during the committee stage of the debate.
—There are going to be some technicalities.

—Because Senator Schacht has neither the wit nor the interest to be able to bring about that situation, he finds himself terrified at the prospect of having to turn his mind to technicalities. However, he will have his chance in due course and we will be able to deal with the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I wish to make in a general summary of the issues which are canvassed in the legislation concerns the change in the formula to be applied inside the polling booth to the questions which are to be put to electors prior to their being issued with a ballot paper. At the moment the Commonwealth Electoral Act provides that the presiding officer or the poll clerk in each polling booth shall ask a series of questions of the elector. Section 229 (1) of the Act provides:
The presiding officer shall put the following questions to each person attending before him and claiming to vote in an election or elections:
(a) What is your full name?
(b) Where do you live?
(c) Have you voted before in this election? or Have you voted before in these elections? (as the case requires).
The new provision, which is to be found in clause 66 of the Bill, will amend that section to make it read:
The presiding officer shall put to each person claiming to vote such questions as the presiding officer thinks necessary to enable the person's identity and place of living to be established.

We do not believe that the formula should be, `such questions as the presiding officer thinks necessary'. We think that those questions should be specified in the Act and that they should also establish the elemental question, `Have you voted before in this election?'-not just, `Who are you and where do you live?'. There is absolutely no explanation given as to why the question, `Have you voted before in this election?' has been deleted.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many times has it ever been answered in the affirmative?

—Given the report which has been produced today in the New South Wales Parliament about the extent of multiple voting, we simply believe that that question should be formally included. As to the discretionary power-that is, `The presiding officer shall put to each person such questions as the presiding officer thinks necessary'-we believe that that gives too much discretion when the Act as it presently stands allows for specific questions to be put. Senator Richardson has a concern about whether anybody has ever answered that question in the affirmative. That is not the point. We are not in the process-although Senator Richardson might well be-of writing New South Wales Labor Party rules into the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I am sure Senator Richardson would be only too delighted to conduct the Commonwealth Electoral Act on the same sort of basis as he has for a considerable--
—I certainly would not want to do that. No rules are allowed.

—Senator Richardson has not done too badly out of them for the last couple of years. If I were he, I would not be saying that the rules were so bad when he and his friends have been the primary beneficiaries of them, from that point of view.
—Not necessarily.

—He might have lost the odd one or two but I am sure he has made up for it somewhere along the way as far as electoral legislation is concerned. As I say, we are not in the process of simply writing into the Commonwealth Electoral Act all of the tricks and techniques which have so characterised the Labor Party in New South Wales for a prolonged time and which Senator Faulkner denounced with such eloquent terminology when he was interviewed on a radio program a little while ago. He will undoubtedly be one of the primary proponents continuing to press for the destruction of the New South Wales right wing machine, now that he has the additional resources of a senatorial office to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Although we have indicated that the majority of changes which have been proposed in the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1988 do meet with our approval, there are a number of threshold points to which I return. The primary point, the point to which the Opposition will stick in terms of its amendments-and if its amendments are unsuccessful it will oppose the passage of the Bill as a whole-is the extension of voting rights to people who are in prison for a term which is a term less than five years. We will deal with that in the committee stage. We will move other amendments. Indeed, we have given notice of those amendments. We will also support a number of amendments which have been proposed by the Australian Democrats, particularly those which relate to the placing of other words on the ballot paper for referendum questions, relating to the invalidity of a ballot paper if it contains words other than `Yes' or `No'. We will support the Democrats' amendment which is designed to prevent the expenditure by Government of money promoting the Yes or No case in a referendum, other than in the circumstances which are specified in the Democrat amendment.

We will be seeking some clarification of a number of matters, including the question of why-and what the expense involved will be-the Electoral Commission needs to issue badges to scrutineers, which is provided for in clause 77 to amend section 264 of the Act. We will ask why this absolutely unnecessary additional piece of regulatory nonsense on the part of the Electoral Commission is needed. Officers will issue badges to scrutineers. We have done perfectly well without having to plead with the Electoral Commission to issue badges. What sort of nonsense will occur if the Electoral Commission runs out of badges or does not have badges available? Scrutineers will be prevented from exercising their proper responsibilities because the Act will require, as is stated in the proposed amendment, `a scrutineer shall wear a badge supplied by the Electoral Commission'. If only the Electoral Commission would get its act together-goodness knows, it runs out of ballot papers from time to time at polling booths, let alone scrutineers' badges. We will come to whether people will be prevented from acting as scrutineers.

We will come to the question of the privacy of donors who, under the amendments to section 305 of the principal Act, will be required to give the names and addresses of the members of the executive committee, however described, of an association that makes a gift. Presumably, that means that if a trade union gives a gift to the Australian Labor Party, instead of simply recording that the gift is from the trade union, or if a company gives a donation to the Liberal Party, that the donation is from the company, it will be necessary to supply the names and addresses of the members of the executive committee, however described, of the association. This is an unnecessary intrusion into the private affairs of individuals and an unnecessary intrusion into privacy in a way which the Labor Party has pursued on a number of occasions.

I therefore indicate that there will be a long and quite interesting committee stage debate. The Opposition will have a great deal turning on the question of the amendment regarding the rights of prisoners to vote. We will be seeking some explanations from the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). Otherwise, I commend other parts of the Bill to the attention of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, may I ask for some assistance. Senator Puplick, in his remarks, referred to Opposition amendments which have been circulated. I have asked the attendants and they have said that those amendments have not yet been circulated. It would be appreciated if we could get those amendments circulated before this debate continues.

—Just by way of explanation, I apologise to Senator Schacht if those amendments are not available. We have had those amendments drawn by the Clerks. It was my understanding that they would be available in the normal course of the debate. I apologise if they have not been. Those amendments have, in fact, been drawn up by the Clerks and I hoped that they would have been readily available under those circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Richardson) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to provide further information to a question asked of me at Question Time.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick asked me at Question Time what the results were of my discussion with the Commonwealth Ombudsman. I had to say, at that stage, that the finalisation of those matters was very close at hand; it is now at hand. I propose to read, if I could, the statement put out by the Ombudsman and add two or three comments myself. The heading of the statement is, `Satisfactory Outcome for Ombudsman's Report on Immigration Review Fees'. The document reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Ombudsman, Professor Dennis Pearce, today welcomed the agreement of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, to refund certain Immigration Review Panel (IRP) fees collected without legislative backing and to fund two new programs for the benefit of migrants.
The Ombudsman and the Minister met on 8 April 1988 to discuss the Ombudsman's recent report concerning the IRP fees. They agreed on the following package:
persons who paid the $240 IRP fee at any time under protest can request a full refund;
the Government will advertise a refund of application to those who paid the IRP fee from 12 December 1988;
unclaimed IRP fees for that period will fund a new Campaign Against Racism;
an additional $250,000 will fund a new pilot program on migrant access to Government services;
the Commonwealth will not recover legal costs from a person who challenged the lawfulness of the IRP fee.
Professor Pearce said that the agreement was a satisfactory compromise which met his main concerns.
The agreement acknowledged that the IRP should have been supported by legislation. It also recognised legal, administrative and political realities:
there was probably no legal right to a refund for those who did not pay the IRP fee under protest;
the Department initially had real expectations of legislative approval of the IRP fee;
subsequently, the Department had legal advice that the IRP might be lawful;
it was not until 12 December 1988 that the Attorney-General advised that a legislative basis was necessary;
a full refund of the $2.7m now would prejudice other important programs for migrants;
the IRP fees had in fact been expended on providing an improved mechanism for review of migration decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't those fees go into general revenue?
—I would rather read this statement first before I go to that point. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Pearce said that he accepted the Minister's assurances that his Department had acted in good faith in collecting the IRP fees. The Ombudsman also welcomed the Minister's advice that the Government would continue to provide avenues for review of past and future migration decisions and for possible refunds of review fees.

``In summary,'' Professor Pearce said ``the agreement takes into account the important principle that Government programs should be lawful. It achieves refunds for the least justifiable period of IRP fee collection. It initiates two important programs for migrants which would otherwise not be funded''.
The Ombudsman said that he appreciated the preparedness of the Minister to negotiate a practical resolution to what was recognised as a difficult situation.

That was the Ombudsman's statement on the matter. I would like to put on the public record my appreciation of the work that the Ombudsman has done in this regard. The draft report and the final report were matters for discussion yesterday.

I guess the most contentious issue that I had to discuss with the Ombudsman was the question of whether my Department knowingly collected fees that it believed to be illegal. From our discussions yesterday and the statement today I think one can see that the Ombudsman now believes that we did not collect the fees knowing them to be illegal. He might also have the view that we should have known, or that we should have used a judgment to that effect. That was my major difficulty with the Ombudsman's report and that has been resolved.

The question of whether we should refund fees where the Department was in the wrong is a matter that we have clarified with the Ombudsman, and he now accepts that we do refund such fees and that that part of the report is no longer operative. In the end, I guess, one of the most difficult decisions that had to be made in these negotiations was the period in which the fee should be open to be refunded. Certainly, the letter from the Attorney-General to me on 12 December was used as the watershed in that regard. I think we both recognise that to have to refund $2.7m would impair other programs. Senator Short, by way of interjection, waved the magic wand and said that that just goes into general revenue, but approvals for pro- jects within my Department in the past and in the future are offset by that money. If I am to refund $2.7m it will be taken out of my departmental budget, not out of some mythical fund. I would have to reduce existing services which, I am sure, both the Ombudsman and I would be reluctant to do.

I am not trying to shift the responsibility, but I must point out that most of these matters were under way before I became Minister in this area. It has to be recognised that part of our thinking late last year was that we hoped that many of these issues would be covered satisfactorily in the new legislation. Much depends on the view of this chamber. I am pleased that we have resolved this matter without having to invoke the other necessary steps that an Ombudsman must go through if he cannot negotiate with a department. I found him very willing to be open and to admit on occasions that not all of his report was accurate. But also, under the compelling arguments he put, I had to concede that some of my previous arguments were not well founded. That is part of the process, to and fro, that goes on when these matters are considered. I again put on the public record my thanks to the Ombudsman for his interest in this matter, for the way in which he has approached it, and for his willingness to come to a practical solution that in the end will not penalise the very clients whose interests we both have at heart.

I just say this about the review system: the changes instituted in 1987 reduced delays by half, from 12 months to five months, and cleared up much of the backlog that had existed in this area for the previous 10 or 12 years. That was an important move-so much so that the extra panels established in Canberra have been wound down to virtually zero. That is quite an advance. I regret that the information was not available at 2 o'clock. I have explained that because of another case running at the moment in my Department these matters were not able to come across as expeditiously as I would have liked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.

I first of all thank the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) for his courtesy in handling this matter today. I appreciate his willingness to obtain the information and make it available to the Senate at the first available opportunity.

I am pleased that there is to be at least some limited refund for the immigration review panel fee-limited, I understand, to those who paid the fee under protest prior to 12 December 1988. Undoubtedly there will be some quite interesting issues raised as to how one demonstrates that these fees were paid under protest. It seems to me that a majority of Australians pay all taxes and fees under protest; nevertheless they usually pay them with some degree of good humour. One wonders exactly how that will be demonstrated and, indeed, how departmental officers will know whether some person who made an expression in a language other than English was in fact simply saying `Thank you very much for charging me the fee', or was saying something that might be constituted as a term which indicated that that person was paying under protest. I am glad to see that the Government has indicated that it will not proceed with the collection of costs involved in the case brought by Ms D., from whose intervention in the first place a great deal of the Ombudsman's interest flowed.

I want to put clearly on the record the attitude the Opposition has taken to this matter. I can do no better than refer to the comments made by my colleague Senator Short on 9 December 1987 on the Migration Amendment Bill. He said:

Rejection of clause 9 by the Committee will mean that the Government will have no legislative basis, let alone any moral basis for the $240 charge. It is a disgraceful and classic example of this Government's incompetence and maladministration that fees have been collected, as I understand it, since 1 October in anticipation of this legislation being passed. The Opposition assumes that the Government will refund these fees already collected, and collected not on any legal basis, and will certainly not collect any more.
Senator Short emphasised that later, when he said:
. . . the Opposition assumes that the Government will refund the fees already collected since 1 October-fees that were obviously illegally collected . . .

I pay tribute to the interest Senator Short has taken in this matter over a period. He has continued to press the Government for the necessary rectification of the situation. I am delighted to hear the Minister say that the Government believes that all its programs should be lawful. The principle that Government programs should actually be lawful is a terrific one to put in place. I am delighted to have the Minister's assurance because, after all, the Ombudsman, in his report dated 17 March 1989, in his summary of conclusions and recommendations, said:
In summary, I have concluded that
(a) the Department's action in charging the IRP fee was contrary to law and based on a mistake of law;
(b) the Department's actions in collecting the fee after 9 December 1987 were unreasonable;
(c) it would be unreasonable and oppressive for the Department to seek payment of its own legal costs from Ms D or from any party on her behalf; and
(d) the Department should be prepared to review initial decisions and this action should not await new legislation permitting the imposition of fees.

The Minister has acted specifically on some of those recommendations. He has not acted on others and has indicated to the chamber this afternoon points of disagreement between himself and the Ombudsman in terms of interpretation. As I understand him-I was not able to take the details directly-it very much hinges on the question of whether the Department had knowingly proceeded on a certain course of action or whether, having taken that course of action, it did so on the basis that the matter was still open in its mind to some disputation one way or another.

I will not at this stage make any comment about the new campaign which is to be financed, a campaign against racism. We will be interested to have some further details on that, which the Minister undoubtedly will supply. In the course of the next couple of weeks we will undoubtedly have a very extensive debate on changes to the Migration Act which the Minister has introduced, so I will save my remarks about that campaign and the ongoing campaigns of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs until that stage, which I think would be a more proper way of going about things.

Nevertheless, I put on record our view that the 11,400 people who had this fee collected from them should all be entitled to a refund. It is our view that each and every one of them should automatically have been contacted by the Department. After all, the Department has plenty of written evidence as to who they are and where they reside, and proof that they have paid the $240. The $2.7m constitutes in this case a windfall to the Government to which it was not entitled. It has been taken out of the pockets of individuals in exactly the same way as the $5 arrival fee was taken out of various people's pockets and subsequently held to be invalid by the High Court of Australia. We have no idea whether the Government will simply pocket that money as well, or whether other people will get back any money. It is simply not good enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think I have a Swiss bank account or something?

—No, I am sure Senator Walsh does not have a Swiss bank account. Unfortunately, not all members of the Government are as honest as Senator Walsh. If they all were as honest as he is, they would all have offered their resignations to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the course of the last couple of weeks. Nevertheless, we believe that as a matter of principle the fee should have been refunded.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be extraordinarily difficult for the Department to establish who paid under protest and who did not because the people who paid the fee believed simply that they had no choice but to pay it. After all, a large number of these people would not be particularly competent in the English language. When a government officer tells them that they must pay a fee, they pay it because they are used to paying other fees for passports, other applications such as change of status applications and all the rest of it. They would have had no idea that there was a dispute as to the legality or otherwise of this fee and were therefore not in a position to be able to say, `The fee does not have a legislative basis'. There is even a dispute, and there was a dispute, between the Minister and the Ombudsman, between one Queen's Counsel, Mr Black, I think, who gave an opinion on one side, and another Queen's Counsel, Mr Sully, who gave an opinion on another side. There was disputation and disagreement between the Commonwealth Department and the Ombudsman. There was disputation and disagreement, as there always is, between Queen's Counsellors, depending, in part, on who happened to have briefed them and also depending on what their terms of reference were, which we do not know. How is it going to be established that ordinary citizens, particularly those who, as I say, might not have been particularly competent in English, should have known that they should have paid only under pressure? what is the application process for demonstrating that they did pay under protest; and are most people going to be able to find the records which demonstrate whether they paid before or after 12 December 1988, which I think is the cut-off date mentioned by the Minister in his statement? It seems to me that these are matters of considerable complexity.

As far as the statement goes, we welcome the announcement of some refunds and the decision not to proceed with recovery of the costs which might have been proceeded against Miss D. We simply believe that, in Senator Short's words, the Government is clearly on notice-it has been on notice now for the best part of 18 months-over this matter. It is unfortunate that the Minister was simply not able to accept the Ombudsman's recommendations in toto, even if he disputed, and made a public statement that he disputed, the Ombudsman's reasoning or conclusions in law or the logic of the Ombudsman's report. Nevertheless, he accepted that the Ombudsman had made certain recommendations which should be acted upon.

I am glad Senator Walsh is in the chamber because he undoubtedly will remember section 17 of the Ombudsman's Special Report No. 2 in the Industrial Sugar Mills case, involving the Department of Defence, in May 1986. On that occasion the Ombudsman recommended the refund of certain moneys as a result of what was bureaucratic incompetence by the Department of Defence. Senator Walsh refused to accept that recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too right he did!

—Despite what Senator Walsh is saying, the last paragraph of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs of December 1986 entitled Report on the Commonwealth Ombudsman's Special Reports, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Minister for Finance reconsider his decision in the Industrial Sugar Mills case in the light of the further examination of this matter by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

The report was signed by Michael Tate, Chairman. If Senator Walsh wants to start slinging off about Senate committees, ombudsmen and all the rest of it, perhaps he would like to lean across the bench when Senator Tate is next in here-and Senator Tate's signature appears on the bottom of this report, which asks the Minister to take note of what the Commonwealth Ombudsman has said to him-and sort it out with him. He should do this before he comes in here screaming and yelling about whether refunds ought to be given, who is a bush lawyer and who is not and who is competent and who is not as far as the Ombudsman is concerned.

It is a pity that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs could not accept the Ombudsman's recommendations. One will recall that just a few minutes ago the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs said he was pleased that the Ombudsman did not have to proceed further under the terms of the Ombudsman Act, because for the Ombudsman to proceed further would have required him to make a section 17 report to the Parliament.
