SPEECH.PARA: Before I deal with some matters in the Bill I would like to respond to some remarks made by Senator Puplick when he led for the Opposition in the debate on this Bill. I know that Senator Puplick is obsessed by the New South Wales Labor Party and its activities. I suspect this has much to do with the immense success over many years of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in New South Wales compared with the lack of success of the Liberal Party in New South Wales other than in the recent State election. His remarks about the Liverpool preselection episode of the Labor Party as bearing some relevance to this Bill were strange indeed. If I recollect correctly, the only remarks he made that suggested that my new colleague Senator Faulkner and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, had been involved in some sort of rorting were to do with the ALP branch boundaries in the Liverpool electorate. Of course, these branch boundaries have nothing to do with electoral boundaries, subdivisional boundaries or electoral rolls.

For Senator Puplick to say that the New South Wales ALP is trying to rort the electoral system in this legislation because of the episode of the Liverpool preselection is a complete furphy. The dispute over the boundary between two branches in Liverpool has nothing to do with the legislation here. I am sure that even Senator Puplick would admit that, in the conclusion of the saga of the Liverpool preselection, the Labor Party endorsed an excellent candidate-in fact, such an excellent candidate that the Liberal Party was not game to nominate a candidate to stand against him in the by-election.

Senator Puplick could of course be a little sensitive on matters relating to the Liberal Party and the Labor Party in New South Wales and preselection. He has been through a very exhausting and, I suspect, emotionally debilitating preselection campaign with Senator Bronwyn Bishop from New South Wales from the Liberal Party for the next half Senate election. I can remember certainly, Senator Puplick's supporters making quite public their remarks about the unfair way in which Senator Bishop was conducting her campaign for preselection. There were suggestions of, I think, up to $20,000 being spent by Senator Bishop or her supporters organising cocktail parties, arranging for visits all over the State and so on. This was implied by Senator Puplick's supporters as being extremely unfair and a perversion of the Liberal Party preselection process. In view of the fact that Senator Puplick has been a victim of the New South Wales Liberal Party preselection process, he should address his remarks about preselection to the Liberal Party of New South Wales rather than casting stones at the ALP.

In view of Senator Puplick's remarks about multiple voting, the integrity of the rolls and so on, one cannot let pass the accusations that Senator Bishop made prior to the New South Wales election about 400 so-called dead people voting in the Castlereagh by-election in 1980. The Electoral Matters Committee received a submission from the Commonwealth Electoral Commission in October 1988 dealing with these accusations, and that has now been made public. I want to put before the Senate the findings of the Commission. I hope that at the end of my remarks Senator Bishop will have the good grace to apologise both to this chamber, where she made her accusations, and to the New South Wales electoral officials for her disgraceful attack. As I will point out to the Senate, the evidence is overwhelming that there was not a scintilla of evidence for her astounding accusations. Senator Bishop, as reported in the Hansard record for 17 March 1988, said:

The year 1980 saw the calling of the by-election for Castlereagh, a country seat which had been held by Premier Renshaw . . . In 1980, when that by-election was called upon the retirement of Mr Renshaw, 28,828 voters were enrolled. Of that number, 18,112 in fact voted. Those are most interesting figures. We can see that the margin by which the Labor Party won that seat was in the region of 660 votes. If one-half of those people had changed their vote, of course, there would have been a different result.
The Electoral Commission submission stated:
Senator Bishop then quoted from a tape which she subsequently tabled of a speech allegedly made by one John Patrick Begg at Wyong Creek hall in 1984. This is what Mr Begg allegedly said:

I just sat down one day and I, you know, sort of got myself and I thought to myself-this is going to be close. Now, you know, I then went down-there's one office, the regional newspaper office, and Castlereagh started at Dubbo and went right through to Bourke-it was huge-big electorate-and I went down to the local thing and I went-it took me two days-and I went through twelve months and looked at the obituaries and I got everyone that died in the past 12 months and then I compared them to see if they were on the roll and there were 400 on the roll. So I sent little people out to vote for them on these blokes' behalfs and, do you realise, we won the seat by 330 votes.
The Electoral Commission went on:

The Electoral Commission is in no position to assess the authenticity of the tape or to suggest whether the apparent incoherence of Mr Begg in the extract resulted from difficulties in transcribing a poor tape or reflected on his condition at the time when the recording was made. What it can say, however, is that there are substantial flaws in the story, some of which have already been raised, such that it is astonishing that the Liberal Party submission endeavours to resurrect so discredited an anecdote, not the least in the same document in which it advocates a return to subdivisional voting. The NSW State electoral district of Castlereagh was that rare phenomenon, an electoral district in which the number of small subdivisions ought to have provided protection against the personation alleged to have taken place there in 1980.
The Commission went on:

Each of the highlighted passages in Senator Bishop's statement will be considered in turn. Firstly, in 1980 when that by-election was called upon the retirement of Mr Renshaw, 28,828 voters were enrolled. Of that number, 18,112 in fact voted. That is the statement that Bronwyn Bishop made. The number enrolled at the by-election on 23 February 1980 was 21,828, not 28,828. The effect of misreporting the enrolment is to suggest that a poor turnout, 62.83 per cent, reflected a poor roll, whereas the actual turnout of 82.71 per cent which is shown on the return printed in the New South Wales parliamentary papers is unexceptional for a by-election.

Senator Bishop asserted that the margin by which the Labor Party won that seat was in the region of 660 votes and that if half of those people had changed their vote there would, of course, have been a different result. The Commission commented:
The successful ALP candidate polled 9,327, the losing Country Party candidate 8,651.

So the difference between the two is 676 votes-indeed, in the region of 660. But the allegation is that 400 cemetery votes were cast, and these cannot be counted as changes transferred from one candidate to another as is the case, for example, with the miscounting of ballot papers. Even if 400 spurious votes cast in the names of 400 dead electors for the ALP candidate had been identified and disallowed, the successful candidate's vote would have fallen to 6,927 and he would still have won by a margin of 276.
The Commission continues:

Unless the supposition is that the 400 dead had not been voted by the Labor Party they would have been voted by the Country Party they can be counted only on one side of the equation, not both. Nevertheless in the face of the obvious arithmetic to the contrary the Liberal Party submits that paragraph 5 (iv) repeats the claim that Labor uses the names of 400 dead people to win the seat in a close election.

The Electoral Commission then looks at the submission in considerable detail in relation to the number of so-called obituaries in the local press in the electorate of Castlereagh. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate the rest of that information in Hansard.

I now wish to turn to some of the major points of the Bill itself. I think one of the most important reforms of this Bill deals with the area of hospital voting. I note that the Opposition has raised an amendment about allowing candidates some access to hospitals and prescribed institutions. Personally I think there may be some merit in that, but I would like to see the wording of that amendment and the regulations and arrangements under which it would operate. The particularly important reform in hospital voting is the proposal that as they go through the wards the staff from the Electoral Commission will have with them the how to vote cards from the registered parties. We have had this system in South Australia for State elections since 1976 and it has proved extremely beneficial to the voters. When they are in their beds or convalescing in institutions they may not have details of where they are enrolled, let alone who the candidates are. Once that is able to be determined they can be given a how to vote card on request to the officials, and that can assist them in casting a formal vote. That will improve on the present system, which relies on how to vote cards, if they are sent to the institution, being distributed by political parties. The staff of the institution are relied on to distribute the how to vote cards, which often leads to allegations that the staff are being politically biased in distributing how to vote cards for only one party or the other.

The Act also deals with the availability of electoral rolls to members of Parliament, both House of Representatives members and senators. There have been consistent complaints before the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and also amongst members of Parliament-who have raised the matter publicly-that the availability of electoral rolls has been limited. The Act now requires a set of electoral rolls to be provided once in every term of the Parliament. That is a very necessary resource to be provided to members of Parliament. Ancillary to that amendment is the preclusion of the use of the electronic rolls for commercial activity. This is to ensure-I hope no member of Parliament or any member of a political party would consider this-that the computer tapes of the electoral rolls are not sold to a commercial organisation, which obviously would be very beneficial to the commercial activities of direct mail companies.

The Bill contains a number of other amendments which will improve the procedures for the administration of the public disclosure and public funding provisions of the Act. That will further improve the Act. As time goes on we will get more experience of the effect of public disclosure and public funding and how to keep improving them. The Committee on Electoral Matters may make recommendations, in its report on the 1987 election, on further amendments to the Act to deal with public funding and public disclosure. I hope that we are able to deal with those recommendations before the end of this Parliament.

INTERJECT.PARA: 70. As it happens, there is no regional newspaper covering the area which then constituted the electoral district of Castlereagh. One of the problems which the then Australian Electoral Office's divisional staff responsible for the 2 divisional rolls which overlapped Castlereagh was that there was no regional paper which could be relied on for death notices (which would have been the source of information rather than obituaries). The names of the subdivisions of Castlereagh-Baradine, Bourke, Cobar, Coonabarabran, Coonamble, Gilgandra, Nyngan and Warren-indicate its scatter of settlements. However if there were to be any newspapers which might be called ``the regional newspaper'' of Castlereagh the only choices could be the (Dubbo) Daily Liberal and the (Tamworth) Northern Daily Leader.
I went through twelve months and looked at the obituaries and I got everyone that died in the past 12 months and then I compared them to see if they were on the roll and there were 400 on the roll.

71. The 2 newspapers have been searched for 1979, the ``twelve months'' prior to the by-election. The Liberal for the whole year contained in total 182 death notices of which 141 were for addresses in Dubbo itself; only 11 gave addresses within Castlereagh, and at least one of those was of an infant. The Northern Daily Leader for 1979 contained 437 death notices of which 173 were for Tamworth itself, many others for nearby towns like Werris Creek (12) and Mailla (10), and only 1 for an address in Castlereagh. A further 73 bore no address for the deceased but is probable that most of these would have been for Tamworth and its vicinity in the light of the distribution of those carrying addresses. It would not have been possible to find the names of 400 dead electors of Castlereagh in either of the newspapers in question or any more than a handful of dead electors of Castlereagh in the pair of them.

72. But then neither would there have been 400 dead electors available to be found on the roll unless there had been an extraordinary lapse in roll maintenance activities, which is presumably the gravamen of the complaint against the Electoral Commission or, in this instance, its predecessor the Australian Electoral Office. The most stable component of roll transactions, year after year and whichever Government is in office or administrators responsible for the keeping of the rolls, is death deletions. The authoritative input comes from the State Registrars of Deaths, and supplementary information is collected from death notices in local newspapers. Every month a typical division loses 50, 60 or 70 electors by death deletions. Occasionally batch processing may leave 1 month light and the next heavy but the likelihood that a Division (or the one-third of it contained in a particular State electoral district) could neglect death deletions for a calendar year is totally implausible.

73. In 1980 (30/11/79 to 9/12/80) for example, the Division of Gwydir which contained all the subdivisions comprising Castlereagh save one recorded 657 death deletions; the Castlereagh subdivisions accounted for 212 (32.3%) of these just as they accounted for 26.2% of the Division's enrolment at the beginning of the period and 25.8% of its enrolment at the end. The remaining subdivision, Coonabarabran, accounted for 31 of the Division of Paterson's 677 death deletions of the year, some 4.6% when it had 5.1% of Paterson's enrolment at the beginning of the year and 5.0% at its end.

74. Death deletions statistics by subdivision for 1979 have not been preserved so far as can be ascertained, and only the Divisional figures can be given. As Gwydir accounts for almost the entire State electoral district of Castlereagh its figures are more significant than Paterson's but both are shown in table 5 to document the basic stability of the operation. With barely one-third of a Division's population, Castlereagh should have had no more than 2-25 deaths per month and accordingly would have taken 16-20 months to accumulate 400.
MONTHLY DEATH DELETIONS 1979: GWYDIR AND PATERSON

75. In the 12 months for which the death notices supposedly accumulated, death deletions were being recorded at their normal rate. Data from earlier years could be supplied, if this were thought necessary, but as the basis for the story of supposed abuses is the events of 1979 earlier statistics would only go to confirm the regular working of the system laid down in the Commonwealth Electoral Act in these Divisions and throughout the country. Should it still be thought necessary in the light of the evidence already supplied, the Electoral Commission could arrange for the (retired) Divisional Returning Officer for Gwydir to testify as to his regular compliance with the statutory provisions.

76. Thus the story fails in 2 vital particulars. That many relevant names could not have been found in a newspaper that might conceivably meet the specification of ``the regional newspaper'', and there would not have been that many names of deceased persons on the roll for the by-election. That is not to say that there could not have been 1 or 2, or even half a dozen, electors of Castlereagh who died too close to the close-of-roll to be removed, or after it. That possibility is a matter which the Commission has raised with the Joint Standing Committee in regard to more recent elections. But 400 or a figure anything like it is impossible.
I sent little people out to vote for them on these blokes' behalfs

77. If these votes had been cast as ordinary votes, then personation (and mainly of elderly electors for it is the elderly who are more likely to die) had to be extraordinarily risky. At the by-election only 7 polling places took more than 1,000 votes: Bourke 1,364; Cobar 1,785; Coonabarabran 1,809; Coonamble 1,839; Gilgandra 1,775; Nyngan 1,525; and Warren 1,410. The likelihood that someone could pass themselves off as a deceased elector at a booth of this size in the country is remote. The overwhelming number of booths took fewer than 500 votes. As the then Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon. Senator Robert Ray, said in the Senate (18 March 1988):

It is fairly inconceivable to me that, in a small country electorate with small booths, bodgie votes could be lodged. Nearly all the officials are locals. They know whether Mrs Smith or Mr Jones has passed away in the last couple of years.

78. Senator Michael Baume interjected at that point: ``What was the absentee vote?'' Of course in a by-election the opportunities for casting an absentee vote are reduced compared to a general election and more use is made of postal voting facilities, but for what they are worth the figures for the 2 previous general elections and the 1980 by-election are given in Table 6. Only half the ``usual'' number of absentee ballots were cast, again unexceptional for a by-election.

79. To the extent that the allegation was that a defective roll, bearing the names of 400 electors who had died in 1979, was supplied to the State, it is a federal matter as the Liberal Party submission says. To the extent that the administration of the State electoral legislation might have allowed 400 acts of personation, it is a State matter.

80. On 22 March 1988 the then Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Ray, wrote to the Premier of New South Wales, the Hon. Nick Greiner, indicating his concern that the matter be investigated thoroughly, pointing out that breaches of State law were alleged, and offering the cooperation of the Electoral Commission in any investigations. On 31 March 1988 the Premier replied:

The new Government will shortly be instigating a review of the State Electoral Office. In the course of this review the specific allegations you refer to will be covered in addition to the general status of electoral rolls.
Your offer of assistance and co-operation is appreciated and I will ask the relevant officers to contact the Australian Electoral Commission.
81. On 11 April 1988 the Minister for Home Affairs wrote again to the Premier, saying in part:

Because the allegations about the Castlereagh by-election made by Senator Bronwyn Bishop in the Senate on 17th March raised not only questions of administrative procedure but also breaches of the Electoral Act, I am not sure that a general review would be the most appropriate means of addressing the allegations. I would respectfully suggest that a more appropriate course would be reference, via the State Electoral Office, to the New South Wales police.

At this stage, I have not referred the allegations to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, or to any other Commonwealth authority, as I believe it is a matter which the New South Wales Government has a more substantial interest in due to the possibility of State Electoral Act breaches. I would therefore appreciate an indication that a New South Wales investigation of possible breaches of New South Wales law will be initiated, to which a Commonwealth investigation could then be supplementary.

82. It is the Electoral Commission's understanding that no reply to that letter has been received. The Commission itself has not been contacted by the State Electoral Commission concerning any inquiry into the matter which it might be conducting. One of the most helpful pieces of evidence to resolve the accuracy of the allegations, the certified list used at the by-election which could then be matched with deaths notified in 1979, is not available as these lists are not normally preserved after elections or by-elections, being treated as election documents subject to destruction once the time for challenging results is past.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to a report by Alan Goodall, The Australian's Tokyo correspondent, published in that paper on 22 December 1988 concerning talks between the Japanese Foreign Minister, Mr Sosuke Uno, and his Soviet counterpart, Mr Shevardnadze.

(2) In view of Mr Goodall's conclusions that trade talks between the 2 senior Ministers could lead to development by the Japanese of coal, natural gas, oils, metals and other resources in Siberia, what effect could such a trade deal have on the Australian resource export trade.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) During Mr Shevardnaze's visit to Japan in December 1988, the Japanese Government made it clear that there would be no fundamental improvement in relations, including trade and investment, without a political solution to the issue of the occupied territories. The Northern Territories dispute is a significant impediment to improved Japan USSR relations and meetings with Mr Takeshita and Mr Uno showed little sign of resolving the issue.

The USSR is currently undertaking considerable economic restructuring and is also revising joint venture laws to encourage investment in Eastern Siberia. This process may generate opportunities for several countries to invest in USSR resource projects. A number of Japanese consortia have negotiated with the Soviet Union on joint ventures including for primary industries. Similarly, Australian companies are looking at the feasibility of joint ventures with the USSR. At this stage, these joint ventures are regarded by Western companies as a means of supplying the Soviet domestic market rather than as export oriented projects. These developments are unlikely to have any significant impact on Australia's relatively small minerals exports to the USSR.
On the specific commodities raised by the honourable senator:
Coal

The USSR is the world's third largest coal producer after China and the USA and most production is used in the domestic economy with just over 30Mtpa available for exports. About 50% of USSR coal exports to Western countries are made under an agreement with Japanese companies for the development of the South Yakutsky coking coal project. Under this agreement, the USSR is to supply 84.4 Mt to Japan between 1983 and 1998 with 5.5 Mt yearly for 1985 through to 1998. The agreement was concluded in 1974 as part of Japan's strategy to diversify its sources of supply. Investments by Japan were made in Australia and Canada also at that time.

Exports of USSR coal to Japan have not been viewed as a serious threat to Australian exports. The USSR's market share for coking coal to Japan has increased from 5% in the Japanese financial year (JFY-April to April) 1985 to around 8% in JFY 1987 and JFY 1988, the increase reflecting Japan's investment in the South Yakutsky coal project coming on stream. USSR market share for thermal coal decreased from 4.8% in JFY 1985 to 4.1% in JFY 1987 but increased again to 6.7% in JFY 1988 due to tight supply in Australia and China.

By comparison, Australia's market share for coking coal has remained fairly constant at 42.8% for JFY 1985 and JFY 1986, increasing to 43.9% for JFY 1987 and dropping to 41.1% for JFY 1988. Our market share for thermal coal has been increasing, from 64.6% for JFY 1985 to 70% for JFY 1988.

It is unlikely that Australia's market share in Japan will be affected by further Japanese development of coal in the USSR if the current relative market prices between the various suppliers are maintained. USSR coal exports are currently not cost-competitive with Australian exports due to large transport distances and difficult climatic conditions.
Liquid natural gas and oils

Japan is about to become our first major customer for LNG from the NW Shelf with exports, after a build up period, of 6 million tonnes per year. Japan is bound to purchase LNG from Australia under a long term contract of 19 years. As an efficient supplier of resources, Australia is well-placed to deal with continued international competition.

A USSR-Japan joint venture was formed in 1974 with the aim of exporting LNG from Sakhalin. This project has had a difficult history and, despite considerable Japanese investment, has not moved beyond feasibility studies. If the Sakhalin gas project proceeded at some future time, it would be in competition with a large number of other possible projects, including expansion of the NW Shelf and development of other Australian natural gas fields.
Australia is not a competitor with USSR for oil exports.
Non-fuel minerals

The Soviet Far East region is reportedly highly prospective for a wide range of non-fuel minerals. The USSR is currently encouraging foreign investment in the minerals and metals prospects in the region, primarily for domestic consumption but possibly also for export to third countries.

Japan is currently one of the Soviet Far East's main foreign trading partners, and is potentially a major investor in the region, including in possible minerals and metals projects. Australia is also interested in the region's development, and Australian resource companies are examining joint venture opportunities in the region.

The development of the USSR's non-fuel minerals industry in the Soviet Far East is not expected to have a significant impact on Australia's mineral exports in the foreseeable future. Production for the USSR's domestic market is not likely to displace any existing or potential imports from Australia, and I expect that Australian industry will be well placed to compete with any USSR exports to third markets, including Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 8 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Minister's response to press reports which suggest Government red tape is holding up approval for a floating hotel project at the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.
(2) Has the Government taken 9 months to reply to a notice of intention, which it requested from the proponent of this floating hotel, Cocos Island Resorts.
(3) Does the Government now want a full Environmental Impact Study, which could take 3 years to complete; if so, why.

(4) Is the Government aware that, if permission is not given for this floating hotel by June, its financiers will take their money elsewhere; if so, how does this sit with the statement in the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories 1987-88 annual report, which says that the Government sees tourism as being the economic future for Cocos.

(5) Does a Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts inquiry into Tourism on the Cocos and Christmas Islands state that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories advised the Minister for the Arts and Territories that no Environmental Impact Statement was necessary for another resort accommodating 240-300 tourists on uninhabited Direction Island at Cocos, subject to specified conditions, including the preparation of a resort management plan; if so, is the treatment being meted out to Cocos Island Resorts discriminatory; if the treatment is not considered discriminatory, why is that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issues raised by the honourable senator relate primarily to functions for which I have direct portfolio responsibility. The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The claim that Government red tape is holding up the approval of the Cocos floating hotel project is incorrect. Consideration of the proposal cannot proceed until my Department receives a response to its letter of 15 December last year to the proponent, Cocos Island Resorts.

(2) and (3) On 30 October 1987, Cocos Islands Resorts was asked to provide initial information on the proposal to enable a preliminary evaluation of its possible environmental effects. A notice of intention was provided by the proponent on 26 April 1988. The processes then involved consultation with other appropriate Commonwealth agencies and the Cocos Community. Following evaluation of all the information, my Department came to the conclusion that, in accordance with the Administrative Procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, it should recommend to me that the preparation of an environmental impact statement (EIS) on the proposal should be required. My Department wrote to the proponent on 15 December 1988 advising him of this conclusion and bringing to his attention several matters which it believed he should consider before it formally recommended that I direct an EIS. As indicated earlier, action on the matter now depends on the proponent's response to my Department's letter.

(4) The Government is aware that the proponent has indicated that the proposed floating hotel will be developed elsewhere if approval is not forthcoming by June and without an EIS being first required. The Government is committed to the development of alternative industries on Cocos. It believes tourism offers the best prospects for the economic future of the Territory. However, it does not believe projects of this magnitude should proceed before proper examination of environmental matters including social impacts has occurred.
Yes.
No.

Each proposal coming within the scope of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act is examined on its merits. Being land-based, the Direction Island proposal raises different environmental issues from those raised by a floating hotel. The proponent of the Cocos floating hotel was briefed in detail some time ago by Departmental officers on the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. An EIS was required for each of the floating hotel proposals for which Commonwealth approval has been sought to date, ie the John Brewer Reef project off Townsville and the Fitzroy Reef project off Gladstone.
